text:
I got this in a trade with Wasatch. Thanks John!

This pours a dark brown with reddish hues and a very large head of tannish foam thats trying to overflow but...well have none of that! Excellent head retention and plenty of nice lacing.

The smell is nice. Im getting some biscuit, a touch of roasted malt, chocolate, caramel, and some dark fruit.

The taste starts of very sweet. The caramel and chocolate and some biscuit are pretty bold up front. Another sip in and theres a touch of hop bitterness just before the finish and I can also taste some other bitterness most likely from a dark chocolate influence. This is nice. 

The body is on the thin side but it seems to be filling for some reason; the carbonation is also light. I dont notice any of the alcohol until long after the swallow; thats when I get a bit of warming.

Bottom line: This is quite the tasty Bock. The only "bad" thing I can really say about it is that I couldnt drink more than 1 at a sitting.(see my comment about it being filling)

Ever since spotted Cow I've been a fan. Uff-Da have all the right notes without overpowering coffee, chocolate for the person that might want to get there feet wet with the DARK side of beer! Looking forward to drinking my second Uff-Da with the next spicy dish to compliment! Job well done! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Had a pint of this on the brewery tour. Bock is one of my favorite styles. A rich flavor and great body. Toffee and some chocolate. This has the characteristics of a authentic German bock. Some malt roastiness in the finish.  Im rating this one from the bottle as I bought some from the brewery.
Thanks Danny Mom! Bocks arent always my thing but this is a really nice solid one. Caramel, mild roast. Balanced sweet and bitter. Creamy mouthfeel. Good stuff.
One of my favorite brews of all time, definitely a go to bock. Very sweet and smooth tasting, gets better and better as it warms up. No complaints whatsoever

This is good, but not over the top good. Lighter notes of fig, dates, and mild chocolate on the nose. Aroma for me is much lighter than expected. Lovely appearance. Beige creamy head dies a bit too quickly, minimal to no lacing. Flavor is watery dark fruit with tobacco. High alcohol content completely undetectable. Good, but for this style I expected far more from New Glarus. Bottle.
Flaska på Thunder Bay Grille. Mörkt rödbrun med beige skum. Doft av kola och körsbär. Trevlig dov smak med mörka bär och lite karamell.
Aroma is Carmel Chocolate hints of figs. Amber in color. Has a malty taste kinda chewy on the palate. Another top 10 by the Brewery only available in Wisconsin.

Backlog, Bottle shared with PatrickFannon, Sampled during the Phils beatdown of the Mets. Pours brown red with a small to medium off white head. Aroma of plum, raisin bread, coffee, vanilla, bakers chocolate, rich malt, wood and light cinnamon. Taste is most of the same. Another nice beer from New Glarus

When conversation arises concerning American brewers who make exceptionally good German beers, New Glarus rightfully tends to be brought up in that conversation. Uff-da is one of the reasons New Glarus belongs in that dialogue. This is a rich, full-bodied Bock that pours a very dark brown and has a tan head. Malty, lightly smoky, and somewhat fruity nose. Flavor is complex, even for a big beer such as this. Chocolaty and syrupy malt, a subtle, smoky meatiness, dark fruits, and coffee. When you step away and look at all the taste profiles coming together, it all sounds a bit weird. However, this Bock is extraordinarily cohesive and approachable. Somehow, all the pieces fit.

From a bottle, pours a clear cola color with a tan head. The smell is caramel, molasses, dark bread. The taste is toffee, molasses, dark bread ending crisp and fruity. The body is medium and a touch oily with average carbonation.

On tap at the Mars Cheese Castle bar. Pours plain thin black. Flavor is rich, fruity, slightly nutty, but still fairly light bodied. Slightly dry finish. More on the Schwartzbier end of the spectrum than the bock, but good.

This is a great beer. Nose is dates, sweet malt. Pours a dark ruby brown, low head. Taste is smooth, malt, light roast coffee, sweet brown sugar or light caramel. On the tongue its both sweet and bitter, playing off the sides and middle of the tongue. Finishes slight crisp, with lingering sweetness. Its making me wish I drank more bocks.

5oz draft sample at the brewery tasting room. Poured a medium brown, filtered clear. Very malt forward with a pleasant grainy/bready malt character, together with milk chocolate, caramel and chocolate. Hops integrate well in the palate producing a nicely balanced quaffable beer. Really enjoyed it.
Bottle. Pours a cloudy yellow gold with small off white head. The aroma is caramel and faint roast. Medium mouth, sweet malt, caramel, light finish, very good.

I didn't take any extra notes when I tried this beer for the first time but I'm gonna try it again and update my comments.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Kind of malty smell. Malty taste with a light bit of hops. Pretty decent beer.

Nice rich caramel coloured body with a touch of a cola glow and a thinnish tan head. Aroma of raisins, malt, alcohol, light ptit fruits, earth and some good hazelnuts and pecans - strong and pungent. Medium-bodied; Earthy bite of malt with a bit of brown sugar, raisins, figs, light spice and alcohol initially. Aftertaste shows a pleasant slight sour note of grapes with immediate nutty and sweet caramel flavours with an earthy bite on the finish - very nice and complex, especially for the style. Overall, another great beer for the style and in general from New Glarus - you pretty much know what to expect before you buy one of their beers, but they seemingly never stop their talent of producing great beers in the style - this is no exception. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from the Edelweiss Shop in Verona, Wisconsin on 24-September-2014 for US$3,00 by my mom while visiting, sampled at home in Washington on 25-December-2014 - thanks Mom!
pours dark copper with a medium beige head. Beautiful aroma! Hard to describe, roasty, but slightly floral. Taste is bittersweet. Finish is smooth and warming. Great beer!

"this one comes in bigger than most other bocks, and even a few dopplebocks, as far as the flavor, body, and alcohol presence are concerned. poured a beautiful mahgony in color - thin dissapating head. Quite smooth and sweet. The aroma was subtle and simple, but got better as the beer warmed and opened up. Rich in nose and flavor by mid glass, with a complex warming flavor and finish. Another winner."
Pours a deep amber color with off-white head. Caramel malts, cocoa, and coffee, on the nose; follows onto the palate. Full bodied on the mouthfeel with some rich finishing tones. Nice beer.

Deep clear reddish, mahogany with a lacy white head. Absolutely stunning appearance. Sweet cereals and fresh-cut hay. Note of honey. Slight bitterness balanced against a chocolatey, slightly roasted sweetness. Big and round bodied, very effervescent, predominantly from acidity. Quite chewy. Fairly long finish. Lighter carbonation. Excellent beer, quite bold. Very well balanced.
Bottle from New Glarus. Poured dark red amber with decent cream head. Rich malty caramel aroma. Light carb med bod. Sweet caramel dark fruit taste.

Nice scents of sweet malt with some notes of sweet candies. Deep orange and red colors with a bright tan head. Great, rich caramel malt out of the gate. Notes of sweet fruit, and bitter chocolate. Crisp bitterness creeps in at the right time. Finishes smooth with a nice mixture of sweet and bitterness. Nice carbonation, Refreshing!
Really great bock! Dont get the chocolate and coffee like the description suggests but tasty nonetheless.
This one poured a lighter brown color with an off white head. Aroma was of toasted malt, caramel and some dark fruits. Falvor was again toasted caramel and fruits.

12oz bottle in a teku. Pours deep amber/ruby with a lacy, off-white head. Aroma of caramel and toasted and pale malts, some light hops, light dough, and hints of chocolate. Flavor the same. Average texture. A decent beer.
Bottle shared at the Foothills bottle share... thanks for setting it up, Mike! Light auburn pour. Plenty of sweet caramel with notes of cocoa and sweet grains. Solid.
Bottle from the New Glarus brewery. Slightly hazy mahogany with a tan head. My first impression was that of a mild dubbel.
Bottle. A beautiful mahogany color. Velvety on the palate. Taste is great, especially the first few sips, but it remains good throughout. A chocolate taste with hints of fruit.

Bottle from madbeerbaron. A nice slightly hazy mahogany with a tan head that mostly fades. Semi-sweet caramel malt with a nice graininess, some toffee, bit of green apple skin. Moderate body and carbonation, semi-sweet, fairly malty, becomes very dry, slightly chewy, enjoyable.
Aroma is fruit/berries, caramel and dry malts. The flavor is caramel, dark fruit/berries, toffee, malts and a tart/mildly warming alcoholic finish.

12 ounce bottle poured into a snifter. Pours a clear, dark ruby with a thick head of beige foam. The aroma is musty, earthy, butterscotch, and some toffee. The taste is fairly sweet and nutty. The finish is more on the bitter, sort of dry nut hull type of taste. Medium to full body with low to medium carbonation. Nice rings of lacing are left on the sides of the glass and theres plenty of head retention. Very nicely done.
Not my favorite style, but it was still a pretty decent brew. Very easy drinking for a dunkler.

Dark red orange body with some head, quickly fading, some lacing. Sweet malty aroma, bready. Taste is sweet, lagery, malty, some roastiness and coca, but pretty subtle. Abv well masked. Nothing special but a decent beverage.
Not sure I understand the high rating on this. Nice grains and honey aromas and flavors. Smooth and easy to drink. But still kind of boring.

Bottle shared by Jeff. Pours a hazy dark red with small head that quickly fades away. Aroma is very malty. Toasted bread, toffee, maybe some light red fruit. Taste is mildly sweet and malty as expected. Mostly toast and toffee with some light chocolate, caramel and fruit as it warms. Very smooth. Nice mouthfeel, slightly sticky. Quality Bock.

Bottle: thanks, Jeff! Copper, hazed body with a small red-ish color throughout, topped with a quickly fading, beige & gray tinted head. Aroma has notes of sweet toffee covered Raisinettes, light apple skin, some faint black cherry & other dark fruit with some more caramel in the finish. Taste is caramel & toffee malt up front, lightly sticky with controlled sweetness. Some cocoa powder, figs, & raisins with a little bit of toasty brown sugar in the finish. Not the largest fan of the style, but as usual, New Glarus does it all. Nice & easy drinking bock.
Deep red in color. Malty aroma with a hint of cherry. Im tasting some fruits in this brew too. Mills chocolate flavor. Its ok.

Pours a clear, dark amber with a thinner beige head. The aroma consists of caramel, earthy malts, and mild fruit, to go along with hints of chocolate and coffee undertones. The taste is rather sweet. I find maple, caramel, chocolate, and still some earthiness. Aftertaste is a long maple. Medium to full in body, with a chewy texture, while having softer carbonation. This one is done well. While this isnt my style, others will probably enjoy it more than I do.

Pours a clear reddish brown with a decent beige head. Almost no lacing. Smells heavy of caramel malts and grains. Tastes sweet, with flavors of nut, caramel malts, and coffee. Dont really get the coffee they talk about, but still very good.
Bottle. Pours a clear, light brown with minimal head. Aroma and flavor are heavy malts and caramel. Thick, strong and warming. Perfect for the horrible cold.

12oz bottle, thanks to nuplastikk. Shared with b3shine. Mostly clear, brownish red color. Thin khaki head, leaves good ropes and dots of lace. Medium-plus body. Good, kind of crisp lighter carbonation, and dry finish. Toasty, nutty, kind of chocolaty malt. Some dark fruit. Nice moderate bitter taste, light sweet. Great bock. Had high expectations for this, and they were met.

Bottle to snifter (shred by DrSilverworm). Looks good for the style; a semi-transparent copper with light beige lacing. Smells solid; semi-sweet and malty with some toastiness as well. Tastes like it smells with a nice, smooth mouthfeel. A good example of the style.
The savory malt matches perfectly with the alcohol tang. The balance is impressive especially considering the boldness of the flavor.
Pour is reddish brown with a small tan head. Aroma and flavor are both sweet malts and grains with some slight hop bitterness. Alcohol is hidden well. Very basic, but well done.

Pours a deep red/amber with moderate head and lacing. Aroma was of sweet malts with a hint of hop fruitiness. Taste was of sweet malts with a twinge of caramel that then moved into a mild slightly fruity hop finish. Palate was nice. Overall, a nice bock offering from Dan @ New Glarus.
user_location: Town of Maple Creek, Wisconsin, USA

text: Bottle. Pours a reddish brown color with white head. Caramel, malty, light chocolate aromas and flavors. Really nice, drinkable beer.
Bottle. The look is clear, reddish brown in color, and has a beige colored head. The smell is sweet, caramel, malt, sugar, fruit, and bock like. The taste is malty, dust, fruit, sweet, and toast.
12oz bottle. Ruby brown with a good sized beige head. Aroma is of caramel, brown sugar, clove and chocolate. Taste is of toffee, light chocolate, brown sugar, earth, and maple.

12 oz bottle pours a cler brown/copper color with moderate off-white head but no lacing. Aroma is as full of roasted malts as a bock should be, but I didnt detect any chocolate and very little coffee. Taste is slightly sweet with medium to light body and average carbonation. A good honest dunkler bock from a great brewery, but maybe not quite up to the superlative name.
Bottle. This one is pretty much all grain and malt. Sweet malt and grain flavor. pretty smooth on the way down.

Clear crimson with a filmy head and decent lacing. Nose and flavor consist of caramel, yeasts, light floral hops, and barley. Aftertaste is pale malts with some slight hoppiness. Body is fairly heavy and the carbonation is moderate. Not bad at all!
Bottle. Clear garnet with a big, beige head. Sweet malt and grain aromas. Caramel, malt and toffee with a touch of booze at the end.

Poured for a bottle into pint glass. Nice color and one finger head. Butterscotch Aroma. Very good mouthfeel with smooth carbonation. Not overwhelmingly malty like many bocks. Balanced and easy drinking. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a radiant ruby light brown. Medium to large thick creamy beige head, lasting with lace. Aroma is splendid complex malty; sweet, fruity, chocolate, touch of peat I think - fantastic. Medium body. Delicious complex malty leading to a semi sweet semi dry finish. This is so well put together.. balanced and super smooth..just seamless.
malt, sweet, some chocolate. Tastes pretty much the same. Starts sweet, slightly dry finish, well balanced.

12 oz. bottle. This has a deep copper color to it, or a light caramel brown appearance, I guess. Mahogany is actually a good way to describe the color. Lots of foam sitting on top. Yep, this sure looks like a bock to me. Aroma is raisin, caramel, sugar, cereal (malt), yeast, maybe a hint of toffee. Theyd have a hard time selling me on the coffee bit, but I guess theres a touch of chocolate in there. Very crisp, and edgy, but the odd thing is is that this sucker has a nice formidable texture to it, too. The texture is kind of a paradox, but thats how I feel. Flavor is more like an Abbey Dubbel than a bock, in my opinion; however, I can taste some bock-like qualities. Heavy raisin, and yeast flavor. Very small bits of light chocolate poke through, but again, its not very prominent. Theres a fluttering bitterness at the end, but I wouldnt say it stands out very much. This is good, but nothing Earth-shattering.

12 oz. bottle. Pours dark mahogany with a tight sudsy head that dissipates to a soapy film and collar. Aroma has dark roasted malt burnt toffee and little coffee. Taste is bitter florals with toffee roasted malt and subtle coffee with chocolate trying to show itself. Palate is thin to medium with a fizzy carbonation and chalky drying finish. Nice!
Awesome bock beer, bottle, nice amber hue, sweet rich finish, overall very good brew !
12 ounce bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown with a nice biege head. Aroma of malt, caramel, fruit, and coffee. Taste is sweet malt, caramel, fruit, chocolate, and coffee. Very good!!

Dark amber mahogany pour with frothy tan head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, and rich decadent caramel malt. Taste is a complex long lasting sweet with a hint of bitter near the finish. Full body, soft carbonation, and a oily texture near the finish

Mahogany color. Hearty aroma of caramel, rich toasted malt and maple. Big sweet malt flavor, dark caramelized fruit, earthy nut and roasted malt. Full bodied and smooth. This is like autumn in a bottle. Went well with salty, fried prosciutto.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: OCT 28, 2013 Has a floral sweetness with some nutty notes. I don?t sense the coffee or chocolate that the bottle promises. A little thin for a bock if you ask me. Just OK.

Poured into a pint glass from a bottle. 

Aroma- A very floral sweet smell with some hints of caramel, nuts, roasted coffee and vanilla.

Appearance- Pours reddish brown with about a two inch head at top of glass. There was a good lacing at the top and carbonation.

Taste- Dark chocolate, coffee, caramel, lemon grass, and subtle burnt wood.

Palate- Again, theres chocolate, coffee, wood, and a subtle sweet clean finish. 

Overall- A well blended beer of malt and hops that was smooth and easy drinking for a big beer. Its a beer that can be drink any time.

Bottle. Clear but dark mahogany, soapy white head. Bit of lacing. Nice light milk chocolate notes on the nose, with a little caramel and dark baked bread. Sweet, nutty mouthfeel; smooth, with a bitter chocolate finish. A good beer to ease autumn in.

This pours a clear, medium brown color with a foamy, beige head. The aroma is filled with toasted malts. The taste is filled with grains, yeast, and malts making it very well-balanced. There are hints of oak and caramel as well. This is a nice re-release of brew that I never had the chance to try and it did not disappoint.

Bottle, reviewed from notes taken 08/21/2012. Pours dark mahogany, thin fine-bubbled head with high retention, nice lacing. Light, mildly sweet aroma starts with dark cherries, caramel with undercurrents of chocolate, smooth coffee. Taste is nutty, caramel malts, mild milk chocolate in the back of the mouth, hazelnut coffee. Medium bodied, easy drinker. Overall nice, well integrated, but maybe a bit restrained.
12 oz bottle.  This one is good fresh, or it works with some age on it.  Yet another New Glarus beer that I am happy to be able to just grab off the shelf.

Bottle (trade with Atom). Chocolate malt, coffee, dark fruit,  molasses aroma. Dark brown with a small tan head. Sweet chewy rye bread, chocolate, dark fruit, earthy/ash, light spice/hop in the finish. Medium body, slight carbonation. Tasty!
Bottle at Papsø - Thanks. Clear dark red/brown - white head. Ryebread, sweet malty, red berries, high malty, light hoppy, grassy, caramel, light chocolate, bread.

Bottle at Papsø.
Clear orange-brown coloured with a small off-white head.
Sweet and malty aroma of caramel, bread, hops and alcohol.
Sweet and malty flavour of caramel, bread, hops and chocolate.
Sweet finish.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours hazy dark brown with a small off-white head. Aroma is toasted malty and light breadish. Sweet toasted malty and light breadish. Toasted malty and light caramelish. Smooth, sweet and caramelish.
Bottle. Red brown beer with a frothy, quickly diminishing tan head. Aroma is caramel malts, light roast. Taste is very sweet, light bitter with roasted and bready notes.

clear red amber, small white head.
mild aroma, faint dried fruits.
flavor is malty, hoppy, dark malty.

Bottled. A dark red beer with a thin tan head. The aroma has notes of caramel, malt, and alcohol. The flavor is sweet with notes of nuts, alcohol, bread, malt, and chocolate, leading to a bitter finish.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of GT2. Pours a clear reddish brown with an off-white head. Heavy burned caramel aroma combined with some pumpernickel. Nice malty body, dark fruits, caramel, pumpernickel and a little roast and licorice. No real bitterness. 140212

Thanks to GT2! Amber brown pour. Classic german style bock, with a really beautiful sweet malt profile of brown sugar, molasses, touches of fig, and chocolatey caramel. Balanced, smooth, and damn tasty.
Thanks GT2. Dark brown pour with garnet hints. Huge dark fruit and dark sugar profile- caramel, brown sugar, date, and raisin. Rich palate with low carbonation and a sweet finish. Yummy.
Bottle. Dark brown, tan edge head. Taste is sweet caramel and cocoa nibs. Taste is sweet black bread. Nice.

bottle poured brown in color with a nice thick one finger tan head. aroma has chocolate, dark fruit, dark sugars, and light roast. mouth feel is medium and there is lower side carbonation. flavor has mildly roasted malt, dark fruit, coffee, and chocolate. quite drinkable and the alcohol is hardly noticed.
bottle. pours brown with decent brown head. super malt aroma with a taste to match very smooth drinking best bock ive had so far
Poured a nice dark brown color and has some notes of chocolate and has a pleasant roasty taste.
12oz bottle pours a dark murky brown with a small tan head. Aroma of chocolate, dark fruits, slight coffee, and molasses. Taste similar to aroma, sweet with some earthiness on the finish. Nice!

12 ounce bottle that poured a cloudy brown with aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, touch of hops,  and vanilla.  A light chocolate flavor upfront, with roast, malt, and a bitter/coffee aftertaste.  A nice beer overall.

Its medium to heavy bodied and has a easy going chocolate and coffee flavor.  This is a great cold weather drink.  Pull up your rocking chair next to your imaginary fireplace, ease back, relax and pour two of them in a big glass.

Pours deep brown/black with a medium tan head.  Aroma has coffee, caramel, and chocolate with a hint of wheat and yeasty spice.  Flavor is mildly sweet with caramely notes, coffee, chocolate, and mild spice.  Mouthfeel is medium and very creamy/silky with a roasty, caramel coffee finish.  Nice beer!
12-oz bottle courtesy of James. Brown pour with a red hue and thin tan head. Smells of chocolate and nuts. Sweet, malty undertones on the palate with a sweet, silky, caramel finish.

Bottle split with Brendan, Streets and Big A. Pours a deep murky brown body with some light frothy light brown head. Aroma is chocolate malts, nutty undertones, and some roast. Mouthfeel is medium to thin with nice notes of coffee, molasses, and sweet chocolate - maybe some dark fruit as well. This has to be one of the best Dunkler Bocks out there, right?
Courtesy of James.  Slight cherry and chicory, roasted malts.   Medium to medium light.

Bottle from Reillys in Madison.  Way too sweet. Above average mouthfeel, drinkable as dessert at the end of a big meal, but not something I was able to finish or would seek out again.  Maybe thats why the label recommends drinking cold if you dont enjoy the sweetness.  A little colour, yes mahogoney, and a little head.

Bottle to glass.  Pour is a dark, dark brown, verging on black with a light mocha head that leaves behind great lacing.  Aroma is sweet caramel, some chocolate, coffee.  Nice.  Taste is bitter chocolate and coffee, some nice sweet caramel maltyness on the back end.  Finishes a touch sweet for me.  Slight alcohol warmth, perfect for this chilly night. A really nice beer, one I will be sure to drink again.

Pours deep, deep mahogany with a head that fills my tulip to the brim. The head eventually dissipates to a sudsy island of foam. Nose is rich with dark fruit, chocolate, caramel. The palate is much the same. Smooth, bready, lush on the palate. Overall, a really solid strong, dark lager.
Not much else needs to be said, a fantastic offering from this Wisconsin brewery.

One of those rare beers with a cute name thats actually worth your time and taste buds. Pours to a gorgeous deep copper color. Its easy to coax a fluffy head. That chocolate aroma is faintly there. The taste is lightly sweet but the body quite full. Even with a spotlight up next to the glass it would be hard to tell if there was much carbonation, but you can sense it on the tongue. The finish is long and lovely.
Pours dark brown with a light tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate and brown sugar. Flavor is coffee, sweet, chocolate and dark fruits. Medium bodied with little carbonation.
Pours a deep red with an off white head. Nose and taste are of deep dark malts chocolate and coffee. Was a bit underwhelmed.
This beer has a little too much molasses for me, but you can taste that it is wellmade. Some smoke, dirt and fruit? Brought to me from Wisconsin by uckelman.

Bottle from dkachur.  Pours dark brown with dark garnet highlights, a medium, frothy tan head, medium retention with good lacing.  Aroma is rich melaniodin malt, light smoke and wood, dark caramel, and light woody hops.  Flavor is rich malt, modest sweetness with light to no hop bitterness, allowing the malt sweetness to showcase, yet finishes slightly dry.  Full body, medium warmth and carbonation.

Pours dark brown with light head.  Aroma is sweet and roasty.  First sip I got a lot of roasted coffee and a little sweetness, but it began to sweeten up as it warmed.  Brown sugar, coffee, and a little fruit.  Very good beer.
355ml bottle shared by jsprime. clear burgundy with a tan head. huge malty aroma. bigcomplex dark fruit flavours. one of the best lagers ive ever had.

12 oz bottle I picked up at the brewery. Pours a dark brown color with amber highlights and features a small kahki head that has fair retention. The aroma is rich with dark molasses, well roasted grains and brown sugar. The taste features sweetened coffee, molasses, brown sugar, dark chocolate and walnuts. The palate is full and creamy with soft carbonation. Finishes medium in duration with lingering roasted grains. Overall: Rated to style, I think that this is  one of the greatest dunkler bocks Ive ever had.

Date: August 22, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: BVery, Burnsville, MN Appearance: Semi-opaque dark brown, nice amount of head. Aroma: Coffee/chocolate and maybe some dark fruit. Flavor: Consistent with aroma, nutty, medium bodied, and slight carbonation. Other: Decent, just not my favorite style.
Bottle. Dark brown pour with a big fluffy cream head. Aroma is very mild - just a touch of sweet malt. Medium bodied. Taste of chocolate, coffee, and dark fruit. Good stuff.
UPDATED: SEP 27, 2012 This beer is really pretty decent, but still nothing much to it.  I like some more complexity.

12 oz bottle.

It pours a dark brown with red highlights. A dunkles for sure. The gravity suggests this should pretty much have the characteristics of a doppelbock.

It smells like an American doppelbock, there is just something in every American brewed German styled beer that seperates the two. It falls between the malt bill and the execution and brewing equipment/process. There is a hint of cocoa and rootbeer.

The flavor is more of that of a traditional bock. It is sweet but roasty with just a touch of hops that is barely noticeable but key in providing a tiny smitten of balance. Some notable flavors are sweet dark fruits and caramel.

This is a decently nicely executed doppelbock/dukler bock, but it is nowhere near some German examples. It is just a joke how much US bias is on this website.

Bottle.  Rich, deep brown color with a small off white head.  Toffee, caramel, and rich nuttiness in the aroma.  Plenty of caramel, dark fruits, some dark chocolate towards the finish.  Crisp finish.  One bock I do really enjoy.

Bottle pours mahogany with a tan head. Aroma shows notes of coffee, chocolate, light roast, and nuts. Flavor shows the same with additional notes of caramel, cherry, fig, and a hint of smoke as it warms. Overall body is moderate to full, somewhat sweet, and finishes lightly bitter.

12oz bottle picked up at New Glarus brewery, pours a very dark brown with a red hue in the light and a nice tan head that has lacing through out the entire glass, aroma is awesone, hersey chocolate mixed in with coffee and sweet malt, flavor was very nice but I was still hoping for more, nice notes of coffee in the finish, another nice offering from New Glarus.

Bottle @ home, courtesy of Armin. Ive been wanting to taste this for a while, so thanks again Armin! Dark orange brown appearance with a brown head. Toasty, nutty, brown lager nose. Creamy mouth feel. Pretty hazelnutty, toasty, coffee, light chocolate, brown malty lager flavor. Nutty aftertaste. Does not disappoint- excellent!

Bottle. 12 oz. Split with and courtesy of the one and only Vinnie V. Cracked this sucker open while watching the Phillies beat up on the Mets. Pours a dark mahogany amber with a thin, one finger beige head which recedes to a soapy, bubbly surface slick. Aroma of fresh baked raisin bread, ground coffee, bittersweet cocoa, sweet and savory butter, cinnamon, and toasty malts. Flavors follow through on the raisny, butter toast notes and end with huge amounts of toffee, vanilla, chocolate, and bready hints, Medium, well rounded body with a robust, coppery, and a tinge tart. Outsdanding introduction to a truly oddly named beer style.

355mL thanks to Ughsmash. Live rate into becher. Pours a clear, very deep ruby brown with a towering tan head. Huge retention and massive sheets of webby lace remain. Nose is black cherry, milk chocolate, not sugar or syrup. Some evident and powerful malt husk comes through with Irish oatmeal, raw earthy grain, and savory steak. Very raw and inviting. Taste is pretty much banana split: milk chocolate, decent dessert character, bananas, vanilla ice cream, black cherry. Palate is very rich for style with just a touch of soapiness to remind you this is a bock and not a stout. Incredibly rich body for style...almost hilarious. An amazing treat.

Aroma: bready and caramel, pleasantly sweet, light roast malt profile and hints of cocoa and dark fruit.  Pours a dark amber/brown, great clarity, thick tan head with excellent retention and some soapy lace.  Rich, malty flavor, lots of caramel and bread, light chocolate note, some toffee.  Medium body, very smooth and creamy texture, medium carbonation.  Very nice beer and a great example of the style.

Bottle poured into snifter. This isnt my favorite style  in the world but I  really enjoyed this one. Dark pour with fluffy head. Nice sweet aroma, mostly malty with slight hints of brown sugar. Flavor was semi sweet but not dominated by the malt. Overall a good showing.
Brown pour with a thin head. Malty aroma and flavor with some definite dark chocolate notes. Some porter characteristics.

Refrigerated bottle obtained through trade with cbfobes poured into a shaker.  Pours mahogany with one and a half into beige head.  Aroma is dark malt and caramel, medium carbonation, good lacing, and thick body.  Taste is dark caramel malt, a hint of cherry, some chocolate, a hint of coffee, and finishes with bitter hops.  Complex, but a little rough, not as good at the other spectacular offering from New Glarus.

Bottle courtesy of my bro from his visit to the brewery - thanks ck1!  Pours mahogany colored with that great brown/red look; 1 inch head with nice lacing.  Aroma is sour cherry, caramel with some chocolate and some malt.  Taste is sweet caramel, bread dough, some fruit.  Some complexity and syrupy-ness.  It finishes medium with some sweetness and fruitiness.  Not exactly the uff-da I remember from several years back but a nice brew that I will pick more up of over the near term.

Tasted on 6/8/11 from a 12oz bottle purchased at the brewery, thanks Ben.  Pours opaque dark brown with a thick tan head that slowly recedes to thick and spotty lace, leaving a ton of sticky residue along the inside of the glass.  The nose is dark and roasted malt with dark chocolate, coffee, and just a hint of vanilla.  The flavor is a bit lighter with vanilla and milk chocolate up front, moving to the darker flavors of chocolate, roast, and dark chocolate with just a touch of bitterness.  The body is full with a creamy texture, average, but very smooth carbonation and a long dark chocolate and coffee finish.
Uff-da is currently my favorite bock as of 6-7-11.  It is rich, creamy, malty, smooth, reddish-dark brown with a creamy tan head and spicy and delicious.  This is a very high quality beer.

Bottle; Pour is dark mahogany with a frothy tan head that retains incredibly well. The nose is roasted coffee beans, cocoa, with an interesting modest spice note present. The flavor profile is creamy from the head present, and is carried by the coffee/chocolate malt characters. There is a fruity note coupled with a noble hop presence, I suppose. There is also an element of hazelnuts present here ; i found this brew to be fantastic for the style. A classic that Im very  happy to finally sample

Deep brown with dark amber hues.  Deep roasted malt, dark fruit, biscuit in the nose.  Flavor is roasted, but coffee.  Some dark fruit with a hint of sweetness.  Well-rounded malt complexity.  Medium mouthfeel that is dead-on.  Goes down easy and with mild lingering roast malt.

12oz bottle from Discount Liquor Milwaukee.  2011 Re-release.  Pours a deep brown color with an off-white head that fades quickly.  Aroma is roasty, chocolate.  Medium on the palate with average carbonatoin.  Flavor is sweet, smooth, roasty, coffee, clean.  An extremely drinkable beer.

Reviewed from notes.

Pours a moderate brown color. Light head and a small amount of lacing. The nose brings some nice caramel characteristics plus some light fruit, hints of chocolate, and a bit of bread. The taste is similar but a bit subdued with some light caramel and toffee plus some doughy bread. Good feel with nice carbonation. A bit plain, but drinks fairly well in the end.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-29-2010

12 oz. bottle shared by STLWill- thanks, Will! Pours a cloudy amber color with a big off-white head. Nice looking bock. Will estimated that this beer was from 2006 or so, and that was evident in the aroma. A little oxidation had set in, but overall it was still malty and sweet with some spicy and smoky notes. Flavor of sweet, rich caramel malts, overripe pit fruits, mild spices, peat, wood, mild coffee and toasted chocolate. Medium-bodied, with a malty mouthfeel and low carbonation. Id like to try a fresh one of these because this old one was pretty nice.

Pours deep brown almost black with off white head, aroma of burnt caramel, toast, and some roasted malt.  Taste is much more rich and complex, with notes of sweet caramel, burnt caramel and toast leading into some dark fruit and berries, with a roasted bitter malt finish.  Nice, complex, and still drinkable!
UPDATED: FEB 16, 2015 Much more drinkable than the alcohol content would suggest.  Nice color, complex but smooth. Serving: Bottle and Keg

A: snifter. pours a rich dark mahogany almost impenetrable to any light, except the edges. medium tan head with a low retention rate and mild amount of lacing.

S: smells like a bock. rich caramel notes, some fruits in there, apples and plums.

T: now this is a great drinking bock. good flavors keep the interest, apples, plums, some fig, and some spices, like clove. Great malts in there providing a ton of caramel flavors.

M: medium bodied for the style. very smooth for the ABV. crisp as well.

D: very drinkable brew as with nearly every New Glarus offering. I enjoy the style and enjoyed this take on it. Highly recommended.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a Sam Adams sensory glass. Pours a nice tan/brown head. The lacing on this beer is incredible. Probably the best I have seen to this day. The lines it leaves after I take a drink are so well defined. It was really cool to see after I was done with this beer, but that was also a sad moment in time. The color is a very appealing robust red/brown.

Smell is very similar to a porter. Very nice roasted malts and caramel. Taste is quite similar and you can definitely taste the 7.3% alcohol. The flavor of caramel is very present in the taste.

Mouthfeel is very smooth and the carbonation level is very great. Full bodied.

Wow is probably one of the best words to describe this beer. It is absolutely amazing and well exceeded my expectations. I really recommend this beer to anyone, so if you go to Wisconsin, do yourself a favor and buy a sixer or more!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-30-2008 23:22:31
UPDATED: DEC 7, 2013 One of my old favorites....getting harder to find even in Wisconsin....great dark appearance; taste with a little bite to it; good nose; one of the best

Poured from 12 oz bottle, enjoyed during Game 5 of the Stanley Cup Finals.  Taste was very unique, notes of dark fruit and a very strong malt.  Id try again, not typically a fan of bock beers but this one was pretty good.
A well-balanced and sessional beer with bready and roast malt.  Not overly sweet or mineraly, like most doppelbocks, but with a richer flavor and aroma than most helles bocks.

Bottle from bockyhorsey, many thanks. Pours a full brown color, nice off-white to tan colored head, nice clear ruby hues in the body. The aroma was full bready, darker fruits (prunes, dates), chocolate. Flavor followed, super smooth and clean, very well done. The mouthfeel is full for the style, rich, semi-dry finish. Great job, NG! Consumed with a nod to the Mrs!

Bottle courtesy of decoman from TBS...thanks!  Pours a nearly opaque dark brown/red.  Little bit of a khaki head.  Smell is interesting - some roastiness, some ketchup?  Not sure why, but I smell ketchup.  Despite the intriguing smell, the taste is quite impressive.  Very sweet though.  Dark berries, faint notes of chocolate.  Rich texture.

Strong molasses and horehound nose. Clear dark brown, headless. Strong flavor of roasted grains and kibble, medium body. Kiss of sweet grass in the end. Alcohol undetectable. On paper, this was mediochre, but I really enjoyed it. It had a certain je ne sais quoi. Very flavorful without ruining the taste buds or liver.

For a style that I do not enjoy all that much, this worked for me. Nose of chocolate, coffee, and some dark fruits. Pours dark brown, red hues, some foam on top. The flavor is chocolatey with hints of dark fruit, somewhat sweet followed by roasted malts. Some lingering dryness/sweetness on the palate, but the finish is rather clean all the way around. Good.
Septemberfest. Sample from a bottle shared by me.  Dark brown-red, thick off white head.  Aroma is caramel, cocoa.  Taste is sweet, caramel, cocoa.
Mahogany pour maybe a little darker, nice beige foam. nose is sweet, molasses and coffee some slightly dried fruit tones. warm finish while still hiding the alcohol pretty well

Bottle thanks to daknole. Pours with a deep, hazy brown body and a small and fading tan head. Sweet, maple, caramel and raisiny aroma. Dark fruits and toffee. Taste is dark fruits, popcorn, caramel, chocolate, and prunes. Creamy mouthfeel light bubbles.

Pours a deep dark chestnut brown, almost black with slight mahogany edges when held to a light source. Frothy one finger light tan head with decent retention

Slightly roasted sweet malt aroma with hints of caramel, chocolate, toffee and roasted coffee. Slight burnt toast is evident as well with some hazelnut and subtle hops.

Slightly watered down medium body with some silky chocolate malt notes and some roasted coffee notes. Sweet caramel flavor with hints of toffee, coffee bean, bitter dark chocolate, burnt toast and slight hazelnut. Hops are very subtle but there is a nice bitterness in the finish from the dark chocolate. ABV is well masked.

Bottle.  Pours dark reddish brown with a nice beige head.  Aroma is fruity with tons of molasses and some smoke.  Didnt find the chocolate or coffee advertised on the bottle at first, but they actually did show up once it was almost room temperature.  Rich and smooth.

thanks to Ditmeir for the bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown with an off white head. Sweet molasses, chocolate and vanilla in the aroma. Taste is Smooth malty, sweet with vanilla chocolate and a touch of coffee. A real nice brew that would be great in the winter.

Like Ive stated in the past while rating this btrewery some of their beers are not a big deal, this my friends is awesome it is one of the best bocks Ive come  a cross Picked it up at hill top brewery beatiful place pours brown and red around edgeswith a big thick tan head and great lacing aromas are of caramel malts chocolate,and  slight coffee, taste is a true sweet malt treat with chocolate,coofee and caramel this one rocks

Bottle thanks to guerinfbfan.  Pours a reddish dark brown, with tan head.  Chocolate, molasses, caramel, plum, raisin, and a bit of vanilla.  Tasty bock, well made.  But Im not completely blown away by it.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2011 Bottle. Pours dark brown with tan head. Chocolate, vanilla, caramel, sugary sweetness.. tastes like Christmas! Killed a six pack of this over a couple days and would love to get some more.
Bottle shared at Lithys Septemberfest tasting.  semi opaque dark brown with good light tan head.  Very tasty.  Dark, almost like a dunkel wiezen.
I loved this! Toasty brown sugar caramel vanilla flavor with some complexity in there - I dunno what. Beautiful and creamy. Couldnt drink many of them or al the time, but who cares?

Deep brown beer with a thick tan head.  The aroma is quite cocoaish with a very nice, clean and well lagered malt character.  A little bit of toffeeish sweetness as well that is really damn tasty.  A nice mix of vienna, chocolate and some sweet crystal malt.  Clean but with a kiss of light date/raisiny sweetness.  There is a bit of cocoa/coffeeish flavour on the back.  Rich, intense and delicious.  These guys nailed this one.

Dark reddish-brown pour with a brown head. Nice sweet aroma with hints of roasted and chocolate malts. Nice creamy flavor- roasted and chocolate malts with the sweetness coming out at the end. The sweetness improves as the beer gets warmer. Lacing on the glass. Glad I bought a 6-er.

12 oz bottle from Roys Singles Selection (New Glarus, WI). A bottle of the currently retired regular. Pours a rusty reddish brown, fairly transparent, but dark enough, like overdone iced team, with a fairly large tannish head that dies to a decent layer, laces well enough. Aromas are a touch of floral hoppy bitterness with some chocolate and caramel malts coming in from deeper, a touch of coffee and toastiness make this a calm, but exciting aroma. Initial is full on the palate, coats well with some caramel and toasty malts, a bit further underneath chocolate and caramel coat the palate, a warming sweetness, nothing cloying, with light bitterness on the backend which does an effort to balance, but largely the maltiness is the strength of this brew, without being too heavy or cloying. Toasty, a touch of coffee and caramel coffeecake. Very light vanilla, the mouthfeel of this brew is interesting, thicker without being heavy or cloying. This was a fairly good brew.
Got as a single along with a few other NG beers awhile back.  Like most of their stuff, a solid brew.

Dark brown, luxurious brown head. Malty, gingerbread aroma, plus honey toast and molassess. Thick and rich, very tasty with notes of molassess and rum, toasty, bready flavors and a some hints of coffee, Very rich. Thanks to lithy for the trade.
UPDATED: APR 12, 2010 Thick, chocolate taste.  This brew is what i look for in a coffee/ chocolate bock.  One could say this is a meal in a bottle.
Pours very dark brown with just a little white head to it. Has a roasted malty raisin taste it. The smell is really about the same. Very smooth finish.

Pours with a great, roasty aroma and a nice head.  There is some roast in the flavor but not enough to overpower the malt that should predominate in a bock.  Perhaps more balanced than your normal malty bock but that makes it much more drinkable.

Good bock, but not my favorite style.  Richly malty with a fruity, spicy character.  I get a bit tired of it by the end of the glass, but it would be nice to have around for a malty treat.  Its a shame they retired it.

From a trade with Erik of Indiana this 12 oz bottle poured a cloudy dark brown with  a very robust off-white head and great lacing. The nose  is of caramel malts with chocolate and some ripe fruit. Rich and creamy mouthfeel. Flavor is malty, and the finish is dry. A very nice drinking brew that would go great on a cold winter day and was still fine on this summer one.

Pours a slightly hazy darkish brown with a 2-3 finger creamy tan head that has good retention. Aroma is caramel, sweet grainy malt, a little toasty hazelnut, chocolate, toffee, Flavor is caramel, toasted nuts, sweet grain, sweet smokey cigar, a hint of vanilla, chocolate, light roast and some planty hops. Finish is earthy and sweet, with chocolate and sweet tobacco highlights. Palate is medium bodied with a slightly syrupy entry, chewy middle and off dry finish. Really solid brew, a little on the sweet side, but it fits the style.
Bottle. Pours hazy dark amber with a scant off-white head. Full body, light carbonation. A little smoky, and a little nutty, maybe a bit of chocolate, but this is mostly a sweet caramel bomb.

Deliciousness in a bottle. Smooth, malty and sweet. Pours out a translucent dark brown. Aroma is sweet, tons of maltiness, a little roastiness. Seems a lot less potent than it actually is, and there is zero alcohol presence. I need more of this

Dark brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma of caramel, roasted malt, dough, toffee and nuts.  Taste of roasted malt, toffee, nuts, brown sugar and mild alcohol.  I didnt get much of the chocolate or coffee listed in the product description but overall not a bad beer.  Too bad they put this one on hiatus.
Very nice bock. Dark mahogony. Sweet aroma. Thick flavors with lots of caramel, nuts, molasses, and chocolate. Sweetness gets a little cloying as it goes on, but a well made bock.

12oz bottle from Woodmans in Madison. Pours very dark reddish brown with tan head. Aroma is malty with brown sugar and dark fruits. Flavor is roasted and caramel malt with dark fruits, chocolate, spices and brown sugar. Flavor and palate are perfect. Realy good brew. Is there a style New Glarus doesnt do well?

This is an awesome example of the style.  With an ABV of 7.3%, not sure if this should be a Doppel?  Pretty close.  Its "big" in a sense that it aint Miller.  Dark brown with some red hues.  Sweet caramel and fruit notes coming through.

Big beer?  Eh, not really.  Maybe Ive been drinking too much Dogfish Head stuff.  Still though, its damn good.  Pours dark brown with reddish hues and a nice beige head.  Roasty, malty aroma with dark fruit notes.  Flavor is roasted malt, caramel malt, dark fruit, and slight chocolate.  Palate smooth but a tiny bit watery and not quite as full as Id like.  Still though, great for the style.

Appearance:  Pours a dark mahogany with a dense, tan head.

Aroma: Bready and sweet malts, some fruit and some European hops.

Taste:  Bready malts, toasted malts, bitter, spicy hops, and a little bit of fruitiness.

Mouthfeel: Heavy/full bodied.

Overall:  A beautiful bold bock.  Oozing with the right amount of sweetness and bitterness, and not to think, yet not too thick.

Courtesy fantomas23. Pours a dark brown color with some reddish tint to it. A small, but foamy tan head  crowns the top and leaves rings of lacing behind. The aroma is nice and shows dark chocolate and roasted coffee as the malt base along with some dark fruit of raisins and figs. The flavor shows more of the figs, raisins, and plums and are blended really well with the smooth, rich chocolate. The roasted coffee comes through as well and leaves a nice bitterness on the backend. Medium bodied with good carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel lead to a roasted chocolate finish. This is a really tasty beer. Another winner from New Glarus.
Aroma of bready malt and some sweetness. Almost a hint of cooked rice. Taste is smooth and sweet, pretty simple, drinkable with nice flavors overall.

Bottle - Pours dark rosy-brown with a cream colored head thats gone quickly. Aroma is sweet malt, and taste is more of the same. Its easy drinking, but theres not that much complexity here. I think this is just not my style.

Bottle. Not a whole lot of aroma. A gook lookin beer. Pours very dark, yet still transparent, with about a 1" foamy head that settles but never quite leaves. A little bit of lacing going on. A very full flavor with, but nothing really sticks out (in a good way). Its feels full, yet not too busy. Very well balanced.

2008 Bottle - Thanks buckeybeer! - Pours a bocky brown with a dissipating creme coloured head...aroma is molassas malt, cocoa and a bit of dried fruit, a bit of grain...flavour is similarly sweet, roasted cereal, hint of smoke...finish is syrupy and sweet, nice stuff!
not a big bock guy, but i enjoyed this beer.  pours mahogany.  thanks to beth for the beer.

I have long been a fan of bock beers living 10 years with another brewer that understands them in New Ulm, MN, Schells Brewery.  This one is just about as good as it gets.  Complex flavors, different than you can find in other styles of beer.  Maybe it is more what it doesnt have, because the main flavors of dark chocolate and coffee, dark malt and dark fruit, with a bit of hard old time candy are found it other beers, but there is often other things that are mixed in that are not present here.  Its a beer that doesnt try to be all things, but tries to be very good at just a few things.  Well worth a go.

Got this as a bonus.  Read a couple ratings before i opened this, and it sounded good for today.  Not sure if dunkler bocks are supposed to have this much chocolate and cocoa flavor to it, but it works very well.  Not a terrible amount, it works real well.  A lighter mouthfeel, but the flavors used almost makes me expect it to be heavier.  All the flavors come together nicely, and the 7% isnt noticeable at all, making it a nice easy drinking beer.

New Glarus brings it with every beer. This was no exception, although perhaps just the style itself isnt something I enjoy immensley. The beer starts out with a nice chesnut brown color sitting under a 2-finger tan head. Mostly clear with a touch of haze to it. The aroma I could get was lightly roasted malts with a bit of caramel to it. Flavor was pretty much the same...light roasted malts and caramel. Hides the alcohol really well, as it was a nice smooth beer without any unpleasant harshness. I can see the quaffability factor being really high with this beer. Another quality beer in the New Glarus gallery.

12oz bottle.  Thick, dark amber-brown color.  Foamy beige head which fades out.  Sweet pungent dark malt aromas, some raisin and fig perhaps.  The taste is rich but smooth.  Lots of chocolate and dark malt flavors, some capturing the darker Brown Ale characteristics.  This is a great American Bock beer, which could easily hold its own against a quality German example.  A great beer, underrated.

Bottle.  Rich and dark amber pour and a little bit of carbonation.  Very pleasant malty and slightly cherry aroma.  Flavor was also malty, caramel and some chocolate.  A little warming on the finish.  Another solid NG brew.

Another gem from noncaloric.  Damn generous trader.  Pours a dark brown with a really nice light tan head.  Aroma is full of sweet malt, roasted malt, chocolate, fruit and some caramel.  Flavor has a facefull of malt. Both sweet and roasted.  Toffee notes are present and some light chocolate is noticeable as well.  This is a fun and delicious beer.  Good stuff.

(bottle) Pours dark brown with reddish tinges and a small off-white head.  Aroma is really great, and possesses everything one would look for in a bock.  Lightly toasted malt, sweet chocolate, significant tart cherry, and even a hint of must.  This strong cherry scent really sets it apart from other bocks.  The taste is lightly tart, toasted, and sweet, which combines into something great and extremely sessionable.  The tastes are tart cherry again, chocolate, and a light roasted coffee on the finish.  Medium mouthfeel with just a touch too much carbonation.  This is really good, and is yet another winner from New Glarus.
Bottle, hardly any head, a nice mouth feeling but hardly any of the bock taste I was a bit let down.

Bottle, pours a red-brown body with a two-finger, creamy, beige head.  Aroma of sweet malts, caramel, toffee, and a hint of coffee.  Flavor of sweet malts, cocoa, and molasses with an undertone of dark fruit and prunes.  Medium bodied with a sweet fruit finish.
Aroma is musty, but sweet. Pours dark dark brown with offwhite head. Notes of coffee, chocolate, and just a hint of molasses.  Hits the palate with a slightly sour, but refreshing palate.

Bottle.   Pours a brown color with a medium beige colored head.   Aroma is dark fruit, molasses, malt.   Flavor is molasses, brown sugar, raisin, caramel.   Palate is medium bodied, medium carbonation, finished sweet.   Greta stuff.
Deep amber color with a very nice tan head. Aroma of coffee with a hint of dark chocolate. Taste is rich and malty with a hint of coffee and a slightly dry finish.

courtesy of tpd975, thanks for sharing this fantastic beer.
New Glarus has once again, nailed the style by bringing forth an outstanding Bock.
Pours a deep copper with thick frothy  mahogany head and light golden lacing.
Aroma has strong notes of dark fruits, molasses, grains.
Taste of light chocolate malts, dark fruits with cherry and strong finish of figs. The overall mix of the chocolate / molasses and grains give the beer a thick mouthfeel, add to it the amazing result of the strong dark fruit presence, and you get another stellar homerun by New Glarus. Pure goodness, and a great Bock.

12 ounce bottle brought to me by a friend. Pours a chocolate brown color with a medium tan head. Low head retention and lacing. Big malty aroma with caramel and maple notes. Taste is sweet malts, caramel, chocolate and sublte dark fruits. Medium bodied.

Pours a dirty dark reddish brown.  Scent is chocolate, caramel and molasses with a malty finish.  Taste is as expected from the smell, identical.  Malty chocolate dominates the bock.  A surprisingly smooth finish is present.  A beer that can be enjoyed all night.

Pours a very dark murky brown with a small thin beige head.  Smells german, grainy, hay, light chocolate, roast and raisins.  Great first taste, smooth and dry, very mellow attack, balanced with just enough chocolate sweetness, some hay and light roast.  The chocolate is fantastic!  Perfect body... I am gulping this stuff down, medium/full with super fine velvet carbonation, lightly syrupy but it works perfectly with the flavor.   The alcohol adds some nice warmth and compliments the authentic german flavors perfectly.  Long chocolately hay finish.   Love it.

Bottle. Pours with a dark color and syrupy consistency. This is very smooth and can almost be called a malt bomb. Deep complex caramel flavors, paired with chocolate notes. Fairly heavy on the palate, an excellent beer.

A bit too sweet for my taste, but not a bad beer. Very dark in the glass. Not much head. Some chocolate and caramel hints in the flavor. Easily drinkable and creamy mouthfeel. Nice to see a brewery that tries so many different things and does them all so well.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2009 12oz bottle (aged for awhile in the fridge).... pours a barely penetrable dark brown with a thin, soapy white head... toasty chocolate and caramel malts with a soft dark fruitiness....sweeter chocolate and caramel flavors with dark fruit notes.  nice creamy mouthfeel that and goes down quite easily.

Bottle: Poured a deep burgundy color bock with a large foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma consists of loads of caramel malt with a nice mix of toffee and molasses. Taste is also quite rich with some nice touch of caramel and a sweet finish including notes of toffee and molasses. I thought this was still easily drinkable while maintaining quite a malt bill along the way. I very much enjoyed this one and wouldnt mind having regular access to this.

The aroma is of sweet malt and biscuits, as well as a slight coffee roast.  A moderate amount of head and residual lacing was present.  In my glass, the more than adequate carbonation was constantly present.  The taste was very sweet with brown and turbanado sugars, and just enough malt to balance.  A very faithful bock that you could drink maybe two of in a session.  Nice and hearty.
user_location: Lake in the Hills, Illinois, USA

text: Had this on brewery tour with cblado.  Dark brown with caramel, chocolate, and malty notes.  Although I am not a bock fan,  this one is very well done.

[Bottle] Pours a clearish brown with a medium beige head. Aroma is lots of caramel and some standard lagery yeast character. Flavor is nice and solidly malty. Mostly the caramel coming through with maybe a touch of chocolate. Nice and smooth, with a nice, slightly roasty and sweet finish.

12 oz bottle, purchased from New Glarus Brewery in New Glarus, WI.  Pours a deep mahogany color, significant tan head.  Very nice lacing too, wasn’t expecting that.  Aroma is of caramel malt with a sweet element too.  Flavor is very malty, with a good nutty taste as well.  Finishes with a sweet alcohol aftertaste.  Palate feels soft and creamy.  Overall a good hearty dunkler bock.

Aroma is maltacular.  You can smell the emmensity of dark, roasted malt.

Appearance is great, clear and dark ambery red.  

Flavor is strong, coffee, toffee overtones dominate your senses.  Very caramel and super malty.  A tiny alcohol tinge, which is odd because the bottle is labeled "beer."

Palate is great, not too chewy and effervesence is perfect, especially for the style and out of a bottle.

Overall, a good bock for what they are going for, a "hearty" bock.  The malt isnt too overpowering, but is definitely the stylistic focus.

Pour is a nice looking dark brown to black but with a dark ruby red hue when held to the light.  Head is a small dark tan that fades to lacing.  Aroma thick in dried fruits and chocolate.  Also some roasted malts.  Flavor is well balanced of coffee, milk, chocolate, malts and barley.  Palate is thick, smooth and warm.  Aftertaste is coffee and dry.  A very enjoyable beer.

Very dark brown with red highlights.  One finger tan head that only lasts a couple of minutes.  A very nice aroma of roasted nuts and dark fruit.  Some milk chocolate as well.  Delicious flavors of, again, milk chocolate, sugar, toffee,and  mustiness.   Some well hidden hops provide a nice zest.  The feel is velvet with some zing and mild bitterness.  I was sorry to see the bottom of the glass.

In my opinion this is every bit as good as Celebrator, and very similar to it. The beer pours a very dark with a fluffy white head that leaves great lace. The aroma is sweet and malty with coffee-ish tones. The flavor is big and delicious with coffee and chocolate balanced well with a good dryness not allowing the beer to taste as sweet as it smells. The beer is velvety smooth and a delight to drink.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2008 Bottle, straight-walled pint glass.  Pours a deep mahogany with a thick beige head.  This remains for a while, and leaves a nice lacing when gone.  Aroma of apple cider, with floral accents and something a little musty.  Drinks like a mulled cider, but not as sweet, hints of brown sugar and mace, balanced by a floral hoppy bitterness.  Very smooth mouthfeel, with a general warmth and silkiness lasting long after the glass is empty.

Bottle thanks to Andy.  Super dark red with a small head.  Aroma is light toasted malt.  Flavor is the same, accented by a faint smokiness.  Nice flavor and palate, and great introduction for me to the style.

Pours a rich chocolate brown, and glowing red near the edges, forming a sticky thin film of white.  Earthy, smoky and sweet herbal wood aroma, like tree bark stewed in anise and dark chocolate.  Deep undercurrents of rock candy, dried caramel, and brown sugar, with just the slightest hints of red berries and banana; a stunning portrait of malt complexity in the details of coffee, fruits, dark spicing and chocolate, cut just slightly with herbal bitterness.  Calm and gorgeous.Alternately, there’s a bit too much crystal malt for the textures of the other malts to show through in the flavor, and it initially comes across as a simple bittersweet blend of sugary coffee and herbal iced tea.  With warming, the brown sugar-dipped flavors of munich malts in dried cranberries and raisins, swimming in a dense bread, thicken the substance somewhat.  Herbal touches of bay leaf and anise are persistent, and somewhat cooling, and that’s a strange sensation in this type of malt structure; it’s somewhat similar to the astringency ill-advised coffee beans lend to a brown ale or a porter, but it’s much more subtle and better integrated than that; it rubs off nicely on the various forms of malt sweetness, and abets balance.Medium-full palate is syrupy and sticky; effervescent, but clingy toward the finish, where a sugary chocolate malt component is most prominent, with a bitter pecan and toasted walnut skin flavor amidst maple syrup in the furthest smacking bittersweetness.  The malt driven character is pristine; this is a wonderful example of the solidity of this brewery’s products when craft and finesse are the requirements more so than attitude and creativity.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2014 served on draft from glarner stube.  aroma is full of malt sweetness and dark chocolate/crystal malts.  good balance.  minimal roastiness at first but evident as it warms.  a very very good beer

(03/06/2014) update: traded for this beer not realizing I had rated it before.  Thanks CLevar.  notice a little more bitterness in this bottle lively carbonation.  a touch of alcohol warming.  pretty damn solid and standing by my previous rate!
Single from Three Cellars Milwaukee.  Less than malty in my book another dud from New Glarus.

Bottle thanks to monger.  Very dark brown pour, though still evidently transparent.  Very thin gauzy light tan head.  Notes of chocolate, not too much coffee on my taste buds; lots of sweet grainy malt.  Caramel and toffee.  A little ash.  Just damn easy to drink.  Surprisingly so considering the 7.3%.  Well hidden.  Tasty.
My buddy didn’t want any ’cause it’s a lager. But Bocks are different beasts. Yes, they are lagers. But they have full flavor and lots of malt. And this one does too. Well done.

Got this in a mixed pack of New Glarus beers.  This is one of the better bocks I’ve had.  Very malty nose with a hint of hops.  Tan head that produced a lot of lacing as I finished the beer.  Wish I could get this stuff all the time.

Aroma is very, very malty with some milk chocolate and slight roast/toast. This is some serious malt porn.  Taste is dark caramel, toast, dark fruits, dark milk chocolate, a hint of roast. Beautiful dark red color with smallish tan head and lots of lacing and deposited foam. This is a really nice beer that is balanced and drinkable, but just a flat out munich malt showcase. I’m loving it, too bad I only have this bottle.

Tasted at the Carolina Crew gathering, Greenville, NC.  Dark brown pour with thin tan head.  Roasted; almost smokey malt aroma.  Very malty beer with notes of caramel, hops, smoke and yeast.  Damn fine Bock beer
Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head. The nose is sweet, malty, grainy, raisins. Very malty flavor, sweet, grainy, lightly smokey. Nice mouthfeel, sweet malt.

Tasted at the Carolina Crew gathering, Greenville - thanks to Facto for sharing! An extremely clean and well balanced bock, a bountiful nose fill with rich malts and some floral hops. Deep candied caramel blend with chocolate and toasted breads, lively mouthfeel. A surprise, one of the most deserving and acclaimed beers of the evening.
Aroma is like fruitcake with cocoa dusted on it. Pours dark brown with frothy tan head. Flavor is like a mocha latte with malted milk balls. Finishes smooth and velvety. Tasty.

Bottle poured to glass.  Sweet aroma off toasted caramel and malts.  Creamy tan head.  Toastes of sweet malt adn a slight acidic bitter to balance.  Medium bodied and complex.  Excellent lacing all the way down the glass when finished.  Great beer.

One of those brews I’ve had a dozen times,and I suddenly realize I never reviewed it.This brew is your classic bock beer. Plenty of sweet bread malt in the aroma,melanoidins abound, interesting teases of chocolates, beefy texture but still with a lager crispness, a malt lovers paardise, rich German malts, little touches of chocolate and sweetness,may be the best traditional dark bock on the planet

Bottle.  Mahogany brown, almost black.  Substantial cappucino head.  Aroma is bready, malty, with roasted nuts.  First sip is very good- malts are heavy up-front, with a nice bitterness to offset.  Notes of chocolate, and licorice / anise.  Great lacing- terrific beer.

Deep, dark brown pour with very thin mocha head.  Aroma is caramel with hints of coffee and malty.  Went down smooth for the thickness.  Tasted malty with slight hints of caramel and coffee, very nice, relaxing beer.

12 oz bottle. Pours a deep, deep brown color with a hint of ruby highlights and a think, full mocha head with excellent lacing. Aroma was slight but it had hints of caramel and chocolate malts, and had a little bit of a sweet overtone to it. Flavor is rich and full. A nice and heavy bock beer. Mostly malty with a touch of roasted coffee with a little chocolate and finishes a little sweet and leaves an almost molasses flavor as an aftertaste. The mouthfeel is nice and full, that’s about the only word I can use to describe it.
Very deep, dark brown pour.  Toasted hazelnut aroma.  Molasses and chestnut flavors.  Quite tasty.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2008 Pours a dark, dark brown with hints of ruby around the edges.  The head was minimal but did leave a good bit of lacing throughout.  Smell was interesting with hints of fresh coffee up front on top of roasted caramel malts.  Taste matched the smell but with a little less coffee and a little more toasted quality with caramel malts and a hint of smoke and chocolate on top of some molasses in the background.  Mouthfeel is fairly light on this and the finish was crisp but slightly bitter.  This brew definitely improved as it warmed up and is a very drinkable bock.

12oz bottle.  Pours a lovely dark brown with a firm mocha-colored head.  Aroma is sweet and rich, with hints of caramel, roasted malt, molasses, chocolate, and a bit of alcohol.  Taste is fairly full and sweet, with a full flavor of roasted malt and caramel giving way to a a sweeter finish of milk chocolate, dark fruit, and a fleeting bit of alcohol.  A delicious bock in all ways.

Ah, what a nice find. Beautifully dark with a light but aggressive head, the palate is coffee and caramel, brown sugar and oats, all blended against a wonderfully tasty alcohol base. Good job gentleman.

Poured from a 12oz bottle and served in a Bells dimpled mug.  This beer poured a dark mahogany with a thin head of tight, tan foam that quickly settled into a thin cap.  A small amount of lacing was left behind.  The aroma of the beer was made up of toasted caramel and nuts, light chocolate, raisins, and a bit of sugary alcohol.  Rich and big!  The flavor consisted of nuts, dark fruits, figs, caramelized sugar, and hint of chocolate.  Just a light alcohol warmth at the finish.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied and heavy.  Minimal carbonation.  A really outstanding, tasty lager.
Pours a reddish cola color with very little head.  Aroma is malty with some coffee in the background.  Flavor is very nice, nutty malt with hints of chocolate.  Very smooth, very creamy.  Nice beer.

Bottle.Pours a clear dark reddish brown, big foamy light tan head, nice lacing.  Nutty malt aroma.  Some charred malt, roast character with hints of sweet chocolate.  Creamy full body with a lingering dryness.

5-20-08 bottle shared with lb4lb thanks to IowaHerkeye! 
Brown black medium pour with a watery creamy ivory tan head.  Smell is subtle to nonexistant malt and has a hint of nuts in there too.  Flavor is roasted, almost burnt, malt.  Palate is nice and on the verge of being creamy.  Drinkable and likeable.
Pour mohagany color. Slightly sweet roasted malty aroma. Flavor is vibrant with malt, hops, chocolate and coffee.Uff-Da!
Full-flavored with great malty finish.  The first sip was a tad bitter but as the brew warmed up a bit the flavor improved.
pours a dark brown with little head.  has a scent of burnt roast and caramel.  taste is of caramel some roasted malt and some hops and chocolate as well.  Not a bad brew.

Bottle.  Pours a brown body with a 1/2 finger tan head.  Aroma is malty, chocolate malt, burnt coffee, and soy.  Flavor has some chocolate, wood, a little viscous malt and etoh coats your palate.  A finale of bitter toffee drys your mouth.
Gets sweeter as it warms.  Stays sweet all the way through, with a bitter finish that lingers and gets stale.  Definitely not my favorite New Glarus.

Bottle from IowaHerkeye.  Thanks!
Pours deep brown with reddish tint around the edged and a medium lived beige head.  Smell is rich maltiness, metal, dark fruit and soy sauce.  Taste is big on soy sauce right off the bat.  Some figgy flavors, but mostly just getting that unpleasant soy flavor unfortunately and with some tart mollasses or maple.  Just not for me.
Thanks to Kraft for this one.  Great aroma.  Clean finish.  Dark fruity and sweet.  Very delicious and drinkable.
This bock pours creamy into the glass with a thick brown body, and sticky head. roasted malted flavor, and filling this beer is semi sweet and a nice treat on a cold day.
BOTTLE! this beer is creamy but not too creamy. its got a coffee and slight choclate taste to it. somewhat like the new glarus unplugged. for a darker beer it goes down easy.
bottle, aroma is hoppy with a good amount of malt. Definitely a tasty combination. Creamy amd drinkable. This beers works on many levals very delicious. Easy to to drink and tasty
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Pours dark copper with mahogany edges. Thin head. Faint sweet malt aroma, nutty. Flavor is dark caramel, malt, with faint chocolate notes. Some expresso, roasted notes as beer warms. Well-masked ABV. Enjoyable.

Bottle from Steves.  Mahogany, thin ring of head.  Nose is caramel & meladonins, some tobacco & dark fruits.  Flavor is caramel & more meladonins, a bunch of fruitiness (bright @ first, then richer.)  Finish has plum, meladonins, toffee, cocoa.
Black-brown with creamy tan head...yummy!  Fresh, roast, chocolate, and caramel aroma.    Roast, chocolate, caramel, and balancing hops finish.  Smooth, with mild bitter finish.

12oz bottle.  Pours a dark brown color with a small off-white head.  Very clean aroma of sweet malts, a little beery, subtle dark fruits.  The taste is a nice, very drinkable, very smooth and clean chocolate.  Tastes much better than it smells.  I could drink a significant amount of this.

Rich maple syrup color with little head. Rich roasty aroma with some smokyness, mild dark fruit. Roasty flavor dominates with slight metallic component, mild fruit, becoming smokey on the finish. Faint hints of grape and cranberry and smoke grow as it warms. Light cocoa aromas developing and unsweetened baking chocolate flavors. Fluffy carbonation adds further dimension. Another solid beer from NG.

Thanks to kmeves for this wonderful Bock. Pours a dark cola pour with garnet highlights. Beige head with nice lacing. Nose of coffee, caramel and sweet matls. Nice mouthfeel full of chocolate, coffee, toffee and pure love. Wonderful beer, thanks Kevin!

Bottle, from trade with akevitt. It pours a reddish brown, clear body with a beige head. The nose is malty-sweet with a touch of oxidation, as well as slightly burnt caramel and some dried fruits. Caramel and roasted malt makes up most of the flavor, followed by a little oxidation and some dried fruits, and a little warming alcohol. Full body, slightly sticky, with a long roasted finish.containing some burnt caramel.  Its a nice beer that I wish was more full-bodied and slightly more flavorful. (080216)

[bottle] Nice ruby/brown color; very dense tan head. Aroma is malty, sweet, with raisin, chocolate and slightly spicy. Flavors are full of malt, caramel ,date and fruit. Yeast character is spicy, slightly phenolic. Very low bitterness.
Pretty nice bock. Deep ruby/brown. Lots of rich malt character reminiscent of a south German Bock. Sweet, but far from cloying. Very nice.

12 oz bottle. Im not a big bock guy, but I do like this beer (just like everything else New Glarus does). Light brown with amber highlights and a white head. A lot of caramel malt flavor with some roastiness. A figgy fruity finish.

Bottle brought by yngwie, thanks a lot!
Grainy. Full malt flavour, sweetish, a little alcohol edge. Burned sugar.

355 ml provided by Yngwie, thanks. Lightly tanned head, dark amber/brown color. Burnt sugar/caramel in the aroma . Also some pleasant notes of a acidulous fruits. Taste is sweet toasted malts with some discreet fruity tones. Medium body. Crisp texture. Ends up  dry fruity with a light bitterness. Yum.

Medium yellowish beige head. Deep dark red barely translucent body. Mild roasty caramelly aroma. Deep burnt roasty sweet coffee and licorice taste with alcoholic notes. Fruity. Dry fruity roasty licorice aftertaste. (0.355l bottle from yngwie.)

Shared by Dickinsonbeer.  Deep amber in color with a small off white head.  Aroma: is alot of caramel, toasted malts, light hints of chocolate.  Taste is alot of smooth caramel and chocolate...full bodied and moderately sweet, with hints of earth and tobacco.  Finishes with some light hop bitterness and more smooth malt.  Excellent.

After pouring, I thought I had the wrong beer. Didnt pour anything like a bock. Reminded me of a stout or ported in body, especially in the mouth. big roasted caramel. Overall I found the german influence and understood how this was a bock. nice job new glarus

The pour is an incredibly deep, dark violet color with a cola brown tint.  A dense, frothy, medium sized tan head shows good retention and leaves behind sheets of micro-foam lace.  The aroma is all malt and fruit, with deeply roasted caramel being the primary component.  Chocolate covered raisons emerge, as do alcohol soaked figs, plums, and a dose of cream.  The flavor is the perfect compliment, with sweet, rich caramel blending well against a massively fruity backdrop.  Figs, plums, and raisons are again all separately identifiable, yet they are brought together wonderfully by a binding, creamy chocolate.  The finish is medium-long, fruity, and clean.  A medium body with good carbonation makes for a pleasing mouthfeel, though mild cloyingness lingers after the swallow.  Pretty solid brew from a style I admittedly dont know much about.  Id bet this one would be stellar if aged in a bourbon barrel, as that would impart a perfectly complimentary element.  As is, this is very good.
I am not much of a bock person but i enjoyed this. Rich flavor with hints of coffee good colour with a surprisingly cleaner finish than I expected.

Dark brown porter colored body.  Nose is anomalously roasty, with a toasted bread, chocolate malt and dry coffee scent.  Flavor is mostly the same: lightly dry, moderately roasty, with a rich and dry chocolate malt flavor, drying out even more in the finish.  One of the more unique and flavorfull bocks Ive had in a while.
Nice aroma.  Fair flavor of malty chocolate flavors.  Not my favorite style though.
poured from bottle, head faded away pretty quickly, laced lightly, could have been a lil stronger a heavy chocalate smokey beer.

12oz bottle - OK now this is my 100th beer rating now let this be a good one. Nose is. Poured a rich mohogany color with small head. Nose is sweet with slight roasted malt scent. Taste is typical of a bock style brew. I am a fan of hops and bock brews are void of hop flavor so I really dont enjoy these brews unless its a Ayinger Bock. This is a pretty good bock with a cranberry chocolate taste. This beer is more suited for wine lovers.

dark ruby with a big tan head.  heavy malt nose.  Big malt flavor up front,  a nice roasted coffee coming through right after.  Black licorice,  chocolate,  cherry,  and raisin as well.  Finishes very clean with a nice bit of carbonation.  Yum!
pours dark brown with a nice tan head,big malty nose,slight roast.nice creamy smooth mouthfeel,wonderful,nice malt,chocolate flavors,really no bitterness....wow this is great.

12oz bottle courtesy of Monger. Thanks again for all of this Wisconsin goodness. Dark caramel brown body with a masses, creamy tan head. Tons of bubbles come immediately to the top. Excellent retention and sheet lacing. Gorgeous! Nose of toffee candy, dark toasty malts, bakers chocolate, nutmeg, yeast and biscuit dough. Fore is flowery, dark malts, some dark fruits, dough, chocolate and yeast. Extremely creamy mouthfeel, medium bodied, very soft carbonation and a joy to drink. No hint at all of the relatively high ABV, this beer is unbelievably quaffable. Finish is chocolate, toffee/caramel candy, plums, dates and a wonderfully long blast of fresh baked dark bread. The doughy notes running throughout really keep any sweetness in check, and as a result this beer never gets anywhere near being cloying or overdone in that department. Another world class effort from possibly my favorite brewery on Earth.

A dark brown/deep amber color. Not a strong/thick head. Flavors of coffee and chocolate. Well balanced. Sweet but not overpowering. Beer is medium in body. Just the right amount of carbonation that lightens the body. A decent bock from new glarus.

Beer pours a very deep brown, almost black with a slowly dissipating head with good lacing. The aromas of this beer are of coffee, chocolate, and a hint of caramel. Upfront taste is of caramel, chocolate, and toffee, finishing with a coffee taste. Beer is medium bodied. One or two of these and this beer is very drinkable, but after that it becomes a bit cloying. Still a nice beer to enjoy, tastes better as it warms a bit.
Poured dark amber in color with off white head.  Molasses aroma with flavors of brown sugar, burnt chocolate, vanilla and as axilla put it.... tomato guts.  I concur.

Pours a nice finger width head with a fairly strong lacing. Smells fairly sweet with a strong coffee flavor and smell of fresh barley like you would smell if you were in the New Glarus Brewery. A very dark beer with a slight dark amber color when held up to the light. Taste is like coffee with a mouthfeel that is fizzy and smooth. Its a slightly sweet beer such as you would expect from a bock bier.
