text: Bottle courtesy of hopdog! Pours a dark, nearly opaque, brown. Small tan head, Nose is alcohol, caramel, dark rum soaked fruits, brown sugar, and chocolate notes. Taste relaxes on the alcohol and turns out rather pleasant and blanced. Sweet malts, soft roasty notes, chocolate, caramel, touch of brown sugar, dark fruits and light coffee -ish tones. Body is slick and smooth. Mild carbonation and medium overall feel. Finishes with lots of brown sugar and caramel notes. Light toasted malts, dark fruits and choco notes round this out. Rather nice bock!

Jeez im a fan of this craft! NEw glarus has yet to let me down. Strong is alcohol, but smooth going down is a potentialy troubling combo if a guy fires back a sixer of this stuff. One of the better bocks out there, ranks up there with Schells Bock brew....

Slightly roasted maltiness...little bit of cinnamon and raisin. Nothing special, pretty bock like.
Great label. Sometimes less is more. Gorgeous mahogany reddish brown but very dark. Nice creamy yellowish latte head that looks like it will go the distance. Clean and filtered with lots of tiny bubbles racing to the surface. The Brussels Lace is textbook, bravo.

Overall maltiness sweetness with a lot of different undertones.
Little bit of cherry. Slight coffee and mocha notes on the way out.
Gets chocolatier as it warms up. This beer is going thru a lot of different taste transformations as it warms. Intense raisin aftertaste.

Interesting mouthfeel. Almost becomes more spirited and carbonated as it lingers across the tongue. Less stringent or prickly and more fluffy like.

Good beer. Some would find it too rich but Ive been permanently damaged by imperial stouts so its ok with me. The Brussels Lace held strong from beginning to end. The glass is toast, Ill need another for my next beer. Ive been sitting here for a few minutes and all I can taste is raisins. Enjoyable beer for sure.

This bock poured a lovely mahogany color and had a small head of tan-brown that mostly disapppeared.  A light aroma of caramel with a hint of coffee. On the palate, the beer was fairly creamy with a medium to hearty body. It finished clean, more smooth than bitter; nicely carbonated. Uff-da!

uh oh, the pour started to look like samiklauss crapfest, but its super dark, very little head.  held up to light shows extremely dark ruby.  actually smells okay.  licorice and alcohol.  maybe some raisins.  i should admit i have a bias against bocks.  well, it doesnt taste bad.  but theres little fun in it.  quick profile, little alcohol.  best bock ive had, but... meh.  finish is yucky... as time passed, the flavor got better but the alcohol taste got worse

12 oz bottle.  Very dark brown pour.  Had to hold it right up to a light to get any transparency.  Coffee and bitter chocolate in the nose.  Flavor has a dried fruit sweetness, some coffee, and some subtle chocolate sweetness as well.  Good creamy mouthfeel makes this bock a bit better from others I have had.

Fully dark brown with good yellow-brown head, creamy and leaving textbook rings of lace. Molasses, dark breadsugar aromas. Bit of coffee and roasted nuts as well. Very coffeeish taste (more stout than Bock), dry, laurel. Lots of dark malts. Longlasting taste, in the end a bit chocolate/mint-like. Bit burning, even adstringent MF, well bodied, creamy texture. Blind Id ventured stout. It misses the bready flavours of a German Bock to round it off.

Interesting bock with rich roasted maltiness, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, dried fruits.etc.  Creamy texture that avoids being cloying or overly syrupy.   Some interesting coffee and mocha notes emerge as it warms.   A quite nicely brewed seasonal ale in every regard.

Im not sure how to explain the aroma.  It smells kinda candied fruit.  Blackish burgundy in color with a sticky soft off-white head.  Very rich in flavor.  Very heavy body.  Its sweet, for sure, and maybe a little nutty and fruity.  Very rich, did I already say that? and decadent.  Would make a good after dinner drink as its very filling.  Cant notice the 7.3% either.  A great bock if ive ever seen one.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2007 12 oz bottle. AttrClear garnet brown color with lasting tan head that left some lace on the glass. Smells of lightly toasted malt and nuts. Silky mouth feel with a delicate sweetness on the tongue throughout. Tastes of lightly roasted coffee and chocolate with occasional hints of dried fruit. Well done.

12 oz bottle.  Dark and deep brown color, almost black.  Spotty tan head.  Has a nose like sweet, cinnamon bread.  Slight coffee note.  Aromas of prunes and musty grains.  Full and sweet.  Lively yet not cloying.  bitter but very smooth.  Bready, pretzel malt flavor.  Followed by a bitter chocolate and coffee flavor.  Dry, but quick hop finish.  Light citrusy hop flavor.  Lingering smoothness with a touch of a whiskyish burn and vanilla oakiness.  This is really tasty!  High and smooth.

Thanks to Chuck for the sample.  Slight roasty aroma, not bad.  Nice dark, deep red color, virtually no head.  Flavor was not bad, sweet and roasty.  Had a thicker body and texture, and OK carbonation.  Overall it was pretty good, and I would have it again.

dark brown w/ hints of red and a nice tan head w/ some light lacing.  flavor is a sweet carmel and a nice roasted malt and some light alcohol notes along w/ some light chocolate.  palate is solid and lightly creamy.  Flavor is sweet some nice chocolates and roasted malts hints of some light grains even touches of carmel w/ a touch of dry finish.  I was surprised by how good this was.

Pours a dark hazy amber hazy with tan head that fades quickly.  Aroma of of roasted malts.  Flavor is mildly sweet all the way through with cameos of malt, chocolate, coffe and brown sugar.  Very good, but the sweet finish lingers a little too long for my tastes.

I cant believe Ive never rated this before. Its a regular of mine because A. its good and B. its quite affordable.

From a bottle, the beer pours a deep coffee color with ruby showing through around the edges.  Eggshell head is initially sizable but settles down to a thin layer with good lacing. Aroma is roasted malts.  Relatively sweet initial taste w/ hints of brown sugar and chocolate. medium weight with good carbonation. Fairly sweet all the way through but cerrtainly not cloying. Almost rates as a dopplebock in my book.  Very good.

This beer greets the sense of smell with a nice roasted grain aroma that has a presence of chocolate lingering in the background.  It fills the glass with a dark mahogany solution that only has a small head.  This beer is thin but not to thin.  It produces a sweet flavor consisting of caramel, roasted walnuts, and cocoa that leaves a nice tingle in the throat after swallowing.

I am not a big fan of the dark beers so my review is probably slanted against this brew - even though I am a Badger.

Poured a deep brown - pretty much opaque.  Thick brownish long lasting head.  Nice, malty aroma. Medium thick in body with plenty of carbonation.  The taste was not that striking - maybe a little too smooth.

Courtesy of The_Enemy. Thanks, Brian

Aroma holds brown sugar, raisin, bread pudding, pumpernickel and spice. Deep garnet color. Pinky thin tan head that is both creamy and bubbly. Mmmmmmmm nice fore...lots of dark roasty pumpernickel/raisin notes. Sweet malt, brown sugar molasses notes toward the back. I dont understand the thin comments...umm its a bock and on the thick side for the style. The flavor is a bit watery and tinny at first, but I personally started to cold..it goes away as it warms. Chocolate notes pop out as it warms. Aftertaste is damn tasty like dark fruit sweetened pumpernickel. Damn fine brew.

Bottle received for 1fastSTi.  Poured into a tankard style mug.  Looks like a mug of Pepsi.  Formed a big fizzy head, just like Pepsi.  The head faded away, just like a Pepsi. Sweet malt character with chocolate, toffee, prune, and some chewing tobacco.  I think its kind of on the thinner side.  Fine enought beer I guess, but I wouldnt pick it for myself.

from the bottle as soon as I popped the cap got a big wiff of sweetness like brown sugar and a strong alcohol. poured mahogany with a light tan head that left some lacing. aroma the sweetness and alcohol went away out came a sour cherry smell, than chocolate, malts, and spices. flavor a lot better than tha aroma, creamy chocolate dark fruits, molasses, with a nice touch of coffee and a slight bitterness in the finish. that flavor brought the rating up on this beergood beer

Dark reddish brown pour.   Weak, cherry aroma (didnt catch much), probably because I didnt have the right glass.  Molasses and dark chocolate flavor.  Bitterness grows slightly as the glass empties, with a long-to-diminish toffee finish.  Quite creamy and easy to drink.  A wonderfully subtle bock.

Poured dark brown with little head into my snifter.  The initial smell was of malt, brown sugar and spices.  The flavor was very full - chocolate, roasted malts, brown sugar and a light taste of caramel at the end.  Very smooth going down.  Another outstanding beer from New Glarus.
Pours a cloudy golden amber hue with a nice frothy white head.   Aromas of spice, a litle skunk and some brown sugar.  Flavors of the same, yet smooth and creamy going down.   Very nice bock...

12 oz bottle thanks to Santa.  Decent head on this brown pour.  Aromas were spice and molassas.  Flavors made me think of a dopplebock.  Rich and smooth,  chocolate, toffee, more spice.  Very tasty stuff.
Dark reddish copper. No head. Aroma of cinnamon, molasses and cookies. Some Christmas spice and dry chocolate in the flavour with a caramel base. A nice dark spiced lager.

12oz bottle as a bonus in a trade with robertsreality - Thanks Rob!  - Pours dark brown with ruby highlights.  A huge creamy tan head graces the top and laces on the way down the glass.  Aroma is nice creamy chocolate, some toffee, coffee, roasted peanuts, and caramel.  Flavor is chocolate, caramel, roasted nuts.  A nice lingering roasted malt finish.  The real flavor comes out as this warms.  It becomes much sweeter.  Palate is rich creamy and smooth.  Very nice brew..  I enjoyed this one much while watching tonights hockey game..

12 oz bottle via trade w/ 1FastSTi.  Poured a clear mahogany with a fleeting off-white head.  Slightly sour in the nose with alcohol, toffee, and dark fruits.  Malty and evenly balanced, some oxidation in the finish.  Medium bodied, just shy of cloying mouthfeel.  Not bad overall, but nothing standout.  Improved as it warmed from cellar to room temp.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2009 A crystal clear ruddy brown pour, with ruby fringes and an opulent thin coarse tea-stained head. Aroma of caramel, light toast, a touch of kringle, some walnuts and a dash of worcestshire. Rich toasted malty goodness, heavy doses of warm roasted nuts, hazlenuts and macadamias. A freshly baked portugese loaf fresh from the wood-fired oven. Rolling oats and wheat tones, with a lucious wave of brown sugar and a hint of molasses. Tart euro hops dry this brew a bit. Finish is sweet and clinging, with aftertones of frangelico and kahlua. Not burgeoning, not dazzling; a solid middle player. On par for the style for sure.

Dark and clear mahoganey ruby body. Frothy light-tan head.
Sweet leafy fruity hops aroma.
Oaked and slightly oxidized fruit, grass, dark cherries. Some saltines in the finish.
Not very descriptive with this one, but overall it has a nice rounded out and smooth flavor. Good bock!

Pours to a clear red/brown body with a thin, non-existent ring head.  The aroma is sweet mixed nuts, vanilla, and strange roasted malts, smells almost like unfinished beer mash.  Not digging that.  The flavor is earthy and almost vinous.  Kinda like a REALLY earthy merlot without that tannic punch.  Sweet caramel malts.  The palate is quite slick, medium-light mouthfeel, but it goes down so quickly, the flavor doesnt linger at all.  Im not digging this NG brew.  Perhaps its old?

I sampled this right at the brewery, and i have to say it was quite a pleasant experience.  This beer heads up a bit and has a magnificent dark color to it, plus you can smell the sweetness immediately.  The flavor has good chocolate and caramel notes and it feels fairly heavy going down.  A good bock thats available all year round.

12 oz. bottle.  brownish amber in color with a great looking tan head.  sweet caramel aroma, just like you would expect from a bock.  a nutty sweet flavor greets you with hints of chocolate and coffee.  medium bodied and slightly sticky on the lips.  just a little too much hop bitterness on the tail on the first few sips, but as it warms things come together better.  solid bock.

Nice dark mahogany brown, with a medium cap of coarse tan head. Deep smooth carmel aroma, peasant rustic earthiness. Not a complicated aroma, but never-the-less full and welcoming. Wonderfully sticky toffee flavor, a restrained but firm hop backbone, clean finish with just a hint of carmel lingering between sips. Gentle carbonation keeps it lively. Clean and smooth, but a nice hefty presence on the palate.

This was a great surprise. I tend to not be a big fan of bocks, but this might change my mind.

Bottle from jcapriotti. Pours a medium brown, a little flat with a small off white head. nose is lots of mocha, some dry chocolate notes. Taste is thin at first, lots of mocha involved here. finishes with a nuttyness, very nice, and becomes thicker as the brew begins to warm up.

12oz bottle
Pretty dark for a single bock. Medium head forms upon pour, then eventually dissipates leaving a ring of dense bubbles along the rim of the glass. Aroma is equal parts sweet and dry-roast malt. Surprisingly, dry-roast wins out over caramel-sweet in the flavor, but it does not necessarily dominate. Aalso some hints of chocolate and coffeee and a touch of hop bitterness. Smooth creamy palate. One of the best bocks made in America.

Pours a beautifully clear mohagony color with almost no head at all. The aroma is of roasty malt, caramel, and vanilla.The taste starts off malty, has malt in the middle, and finshes off with malt. Lots of melonoidins in there. Still, it is not overly sweet, and is very clean. Very enjoyable.
Definitely able to smell and taste the coffee / chocolate undertones of this beer..... Might be a little "too much of a meal" for my liking, but will keep this one in mind for a good winter brew....
Smelled malty, some vanilla notes even a slight banana, and caramel.  Poured amber brown.  Tasted sweet roasty caramel sweet malt.

Bottle thanks to my Secret Santa.  Beautiful looking beer.  Nice dark cherry with a thin white head.  The aroma is sweet and malty, notes of earth and caramel.  Flavor has a hint of crystalized sugar at first, then calms down.   This doesnt come off as that complex of a brew, but it does come off as an extremely solid offering.  Palate is soft and slightly oily.  Very solid beer.

Sharp looking - a clear caramel color with a respectable, lacing-busy head.  The aroma is smokey, worty, sweet - good.  Medium-bodied, it has a roasted barley and caramel flavor perhaps with a suggestion of chocolate.  Having a sticky sweet, smokey finish, this is a worthy bock.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.lakegenevawi.com/>Bouquets of Lake Geneva, Lake Geneva, WI<font size=-1>

Light mahogany colored with a small fizzy light brown head that settles quickly.  Clean, fruity aroma with roasted chocolate and caramel malts.  Flavor is sweet and spicy with a hint of alcohol.  The caramel and roasted malt really come through in the finish.  Full bodied with a slightly oily mouth feel to it.  A nice bock.

Decent brown head that settles quickly to a nice dense foam.  Good carbonation.  Roasty aroma with a bit of leather, caramel and burnt butter.  Color is a nice dark mahagony red.  Slightly sweet flavor with more roastyness and caramel.  Hint of spices.  Plenty of malt to go around.  Thick and creamy in the mouth.  Noticable alcohol presence.  Finish is creamy and has a little syrpy feel to it.  Sweet lingering coating on the tongue.  A decent bock.

Thanks to robertsreality and Secret Santa for this beer.

Poured a clear effervescent mahogany with a small tan head that dissipated completely.  Pleasant aroma of dark fruits and a touch of spice... not extremely rich.  Flavor is dark fruit, cinnamon, and a bit of alcohol with a dry toffee finish.  The body feels slightly over-carbonated.  Overall a nice beer, though not quite as complex as their Black Wheat.

Pours dark transparent mahogany, with only film for head. Lots of nutty sweet malt and roasted grain in the aroma. Initial flavor is caramel malt, with some roasted grain and nuts coming in through the middle. Finishes very dry.

It pours a mahogany brown with red glowing through the glass; moderate to small off-white/cream head.  Warm, sweet, malty, brown sugar and bread aroma, lots of caramel, it might as well be a malt loaf with a toffee topping.  Massive malt flavor, sometimes suggesting a flavored coffee, but mostly raisins, caramel, and pancake/maple syrup.  Just a tingle on the tongue, in aid of the of the palate, suggests the 7.3% alcohol, otherwise it is a somewhat syrupy malt fusion.  A touch of bitterness in the finish, suggestive of roast and toast.  Pretty enjoyable on the whole, although I dont think I would drink more than one of these in a night, because it is too sweet or overpowering in the particular malt flavor dimension (though I like lots of malts).

Small tan head that settles quickly leaving little lace behind. Clear mahogany colored brew, nice look. Nose is nice, grainy, bready, lovely maltiness. Body is medium, lightly creamy. Lightly sweet malts, caramel, bready flavors with hints of roast and toasted malts. Finish is mildly sweet malts, lingering. Best Bock i,ve had in quite awhile. Thanks Roberrrrrrrt!

2 oz bottle. Dark brown color. Small sized very dense white foamy head. Aroma is caramel, fruity and sweet. A medium to full bodied bock. Malts are caramel, fruity and bready. Slightly spicy hops. A very smooth tasty bock. Kind of sweet and perhaps a little syrupy. But like all of the New Glarus beer I have sampled, its very smooth and very well balanced beer. No trace of the 7.3% alcohol. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

Pours deep brown with a quickly fading brown head. Big sweet munich malty nose. Flavors are heavily sweet with notes of maple syrup and vanilla with  no hops. Body is med. heavy. Finish has no bitterness. This is way on the sweet side with less maltiness than I like and is definitely a "doppel bock".

Dark brown/red with a short head and scant lacing, dark malty aroma with a sherry like note. Medium bodied with an almost dessert like sweetness, chocolate, toffee and coffee flavors and a soft finish. Drinkable but Ive had better. No bottling date that I could find.

On tap at the Huber Haus. Pours a brown copper color with a good white head. Unfortunately, the head dies quickly. This bier is candy sweet. Is there lactose in this? Extremely hyperglucose. Just not enough hop balance. Is this supposed to be a bock? Really?
On tap at a local ... this is medium brown with virtually no head.  Its nutty and lightly sweet, candied-caramel ... I didnt really dig it.

Pours a deep dark ruby color with thin brown head.  Smells of chocolate malt, chocolate, caramel, toffee.  Tastes mirror the aroma with a bittersweet chocolate added in the mix.  A bit watery and bit too sweet for me.
Bottle from Facto: poured brown with ruby tocuhes. Malty aroma with some chocolate notes. Some nuttiness to it. Big caramel flavor followed by a little chocolate. Good.
Poured a reddish color.aromas of coffee and malts.Medium body with tastes of some chocolate and coffee.Not bad.Finish was a little sweet but dissapeared quickly.

The first bottle I had may have been infected, as the taste was extraordinarily salty and sour.  On a retaste, I was pleasantly suprised, despite my fear that the New Glarus bock simply tasted like... that.
Aroma is an amiable "sweet" with a little chocolate.  Taste is upfront caramel malt complimented by lingering apple and muted bitter chocolate.  Some odd tastes, like read meat and carrot juice, not really sure what that was about.  Something with an odd sweet and tangy feel to it.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2005 Poured a clear reddish-brown color with about 1 finger of creamy beige head.  Sweet aroma with chocolate, caramel, and coffee noted.  Nice smooth mouthfeel with very sweet and tasty chocolate, nutmeg, dark fruit, and caramel.  Coffee bitterness and some alcohol warmth found the finish.  Just the right amount of carbonation.  Very pleasant!

Ruby in color with only a thin piece of foam ringing the glass. Light aroma of malt and dark caramel with some raisen. Clean and malty in flavor with a sweet finish. Raisen and a little cocoa. A little bit of lingering astringency.
Deep red color with no head.  Smells like an old and dusty apple.  Very syrupy.  The malt is quite sweet.  Some chocolate on the end.  Good!

Appears Dark Cloudy Brown...Ruby Red in the Light with Scant Traces of Sandy Skin.  ARoma...however dusty, smells of caramel chocolate brownie..  Sweetness on the Tongue...Couild be Caramel...Barley, Malt...Crisp, Lightly Grapey/Raisin Tartness at the End..  Thin Mouthfeel..  Very Decent.

Bottle, poured into by Celebrator glass:  Beer pours ruby red amber color with a big creamy tan colored head that slowly fades away.  Aroma is rich and malty; bit of sweet caramel.  Flavor is sweet with caramel and light chocolate notes.  Bit thin on the palate.  Good biere.

Found this at the back of my brother-in-laws fridge... I think I bought it for him 2 Christmases ago. Held up well. Looked OK with a hazy brown headless body. (Wishing all ratings were on a 10-scale so I could give it a perfectly average 5.) Aroma started fruity with coffee, malt and a little alcohol. Bittersweet flavor with coffee hints and weak tea. Syrupy yet watery finish.

it was better than expected after having a few disappointing new glarus ratings.  this was like carmel and slight chocolate and very very little coffee in the background.  meh... i dont know, it was just o.k.

A top notch bock.  Regular bock aroma, but better than many others.  Light red.  Head dissipates quickly.  Unusually complex flavor.  Malt dominates, but there is also carmel and wine.  Sweet.  Good body.  Thin enough that it is easy to drink.
nice smell of strong malt, very deep shade of ruby red, nice bock beer, fairly strong roasted malty flavor, not really many hops to speak of, but over all a pretty solid beer,
Dark brown color with little to no head.  Nutty caramel aroma with similar flavors.  Chocolate finish.  Medium body.  Not too complex, but not bad.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2005 Rerate update: have this one at 60 degrees and it doesnt get much better.  The sweet caramel and chocolate malts headline the bill, with all other signiture bock characteristics and full mouth feel to seal the deal.  Previously had this rated as a "4", but were bumping it up to where it deserves to be.  Here are some notes from other tastings...  Aroma of sweet milk chocolate and brown sugar.  Rich, smooth and very chocolatey flavor.  A great body - a little oily and heavy on the palate.  Cant trace the 7.3% alcohol.  Also have had before and after smoking a Cuban.  Its a great cigar beer.  A solid bock.  New Glarus knows how to do it right and continually makes world class beers.
Medium dark beer with alot of chocolate/coffee undertones.  Very sweet no bitter. Major chocolate finish .
Sweet, chocolate malt smell.  The sweetness hits right away.  Caramel hints with toffee and berries.  Is a little syrupy.   A good bock with loads of flavor but a little to sweet for me.
Bottle from Eyedrinkale.  Nice red-copper color.  Fruity aroma of cherry and rich sweet malt.  Medium bodied and smooth.  Flavors run from roasted malt to chocolate.  Nice.

Bottle:  Malty aroma with lots of caramel and toffee.  Pours a dark transparent reddish-brown with a small white head thats more of a ring than an actual head.  Watery caramel flavor starts out light in the front and increases in the finish.  Some brown sugar in there as well.  Another from Eyedrinkale.

This beer is a dark brown color with splashes of crimson. Thin dark beige head and a thin wall of lacing. The aroma is roasty and malty along with some caramel. Medium-bodied and smooth with a pleasant blend of flavors such as roasted malt, nuts, caramel and dark cherry. The finish is long and sweet with chocolate and a slight hoppiness. Enjoyable Bock from New Glarus.

Bold dark garnet, little head. Big, malty nose. In general, this is just a malt-masterpiece. Subtly sweet and complex with toffee, coffee, raisin, molasses and more. Exceptionally drinkable. The epitome of German style brewing.

Bottle (thanks Shane). This stuff pours an amberish with some brown tints. Aroma is carame and toffee with some cider. The taste is light and medium bodied with some flavors of cocoa, caramel malts, brown sugar and grass. A drinkable bock.
Not one of my favorite Bocks, but not too bad.  Made be beatable in Bond, so my buddy was happy.

Thin off white head. Very dark amber coloring. Aroma is very malty with a hint of coffee and some earthy grass. Taste is an earthy malty honey. Also some notes of peanuts. This is a solid brew, a little sweet.
Love the name!  Anyway, this brew is dark red and malty, with flavors of dark fruits and chocolate.  Thanks, Facto, you beer whore!  :P

Pours a thin coppery head that skeedadles very fast to the thinnest of films.  Remarkedly tiny bubbles.  Slight aroma of ham and biscuits with lots of butter.  Taste  smacks you like a back-talking stepchild. WHAP!  Coffee and pork rinds!  Butter creams and cocoa beans. Damn this is good.

A muddy brown apperance with a moderate head. The aroma is chocolate. caramel and figs. The flavor is rather LARGE with a molasses, sour grape, and prune taste. It hides the alcohol quite well. The aftertaste is somewhat sticky and sour. A very well done Bock. Does New Glarus do a bad beer? I think not.

Bottle: Cola hued with reddish highlights, small fading head and little lace. The aroma has notes of caramelized malts, toffee, grape, apple, grains, and some coffee. The taste starts quite sweet and malty. Subdued fruits and a hint of coffee adds some depth but the taste fades way too quickly, leaving behind a chalky dry palate. Okay brew but NG does make so many more beers I like more. Bonus overall point for well hidden alcohol.

This was a pretty standard bock, dominated by toasted malts, tannins, red grape skin, and hints of prune and raisin.  Differs from some bocks in its nicely carbonated, non-syrupy, rather light body.  Not all that complex, however; as the woody toasted malts dominated when the beer was cold and also after it warmed up.  Thanks Matt (MrFacto) for the bottle.
Pours a dark brownish red with a thin medium head. Aroma is caramel, brown sugar, and soy. Flavor of browm sugar and caramel. A bit watery but still pretty good.

Bottle Pours a hazy dark redish brown.  Small but persistant sandy colored fizzy head.  Nice heavy lacing.  Aroma is quite chocolate malt like and a slight alchohol bite.  Flavors are sweet dark roasted malt, cinnamon, not much hops and chocolate again.  Nice smooth feel but very heavy.  Nice and easy to put away even at 7%+
Thanks to MrFacto for this one

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2004 Pours a mahogany red with a nice ivory head. Tons of malty sweetness in the aroma, hints of toffee, chocolate, and caramel malts. Taste started malty and sweet and finished with a well rounded bitterness. The caramel and chocolate trailed off in the aftertaste. Very smooth bock, with a medium palate and light spicness to the hops. Thanks a ton to Germanbrews76 for all the New Glarus brews!

bottle. THANKS to MR.FACTO for the wonderful birthday gift!! first, i love the name gives an extra point... aroma: mmm like a chocolate malt someone threw a shot of liquor in... a sweet mouthful, light and warming... i really like the way this settles in... this is relaxing me as mouch as anything can during this tight election.

This bock poured a nice reddish brown out of the bottle and was a beautiful ruby color in the light.  Decent whitish head without too much lacing.  The initial aroma I get is a cidery ester, but it went away quickly replaced by a chocolatey malt aroma.  The flavor is excellent, clean malty flavor starting with chocolate and coffee and moving to a distinct nuttiness as it warms up, reminding me of pistachios.  Nice body and the carbonation seems to linger even as the beer warms up.  You cant even really notice the alcohol with this, I would have guessed around 6%.  This is a great example of the style.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2007 Pours a dark brown, small tan head. Aroma is cherries, malt, and grapes. Flavor is malty. and carbonated, sweet malt, hops and a little bit of coffee. Palate is a little thing, but flavor is well definied, warming and complex.
A good bock with a solid body and a nice malty taste.  This is a beer to have when the weather gets cold.

(Bottle)  Pours a deep amber with a large creamy beige head.  Aroma of caramel, roasted malt, citrus, raisins, and maple syrup.  Cold weather beer that nicely warms you up.  Flavor of caramel, sweet malt, and alcohol.

Deep ruby red color with small off white head. Aroma is malty with lots of caramel, raisens, pretty sweet, very nice overall. Flavor is a bit of a let down after the aroma: its malty, sweet, a bit of caramel, but kind of thin overall. Still a very nice brew, with a great aroma.
Dark reddish brown creamy head.Has arich fruity nose with some caramel apple tones.Good but not as cnice as the aroma.In fact I am a little let down and last years was much better.

Nice deep amber/brown with thick off-white head. Carmel, plum, raisen, malt and toffee on the nose. Medium mouthfeel with soft feel and lingering finish. Carmel, toffee, cinnamon, and some fruit notes on the finish. Really nice beer!

Im not normally a fan of this style but as fall approaches I can really get into these and Ofests which I dont normally drink either.  This was smooth with a long caramel taste and cinnamon finish.  Very drinkable and just the right amount of alcohol.  Bring on the leaves and lagers! Thanks Ryan.

Dark crimson color, smallish head.
Aroma, cocoa and cream, earth and bread, soft fruit and cola.
Taste: rich and malty, neat hop attack, giving way to smoothness all the way out. Touches of nuts, lightly fruity, cherries, and grape. Medium bodied, light, tasty, fruity finish.
A nice, easy-going, quite agreeable little bock. I could down a few without complaint, ya sure, you betcha...

A big thanks to Drnk_McDermott for sending me a 5-year aged bottle of this.  Pours burnt sienna with a medium, creamy, white head.  Aroma of malt, dark fruit, cognac, nuts, caramel, chocolate.  Tastes very complex, with hints of malt, nuts, toffee, cognac, chocolate, dark fruit.  The palate is firm, rich, extremely smooth...delicious!  This one has some brown ale, bock, and dubbel characteristics.  As it warmed, I even picked up a caramel apple flavor that was delectable.  This is a great beer, and New Glarus continues to impress me.
Nice grainy-sweet aroma.  Intense ruddy brown coloring, light camel lacing.  Tangy, malted oat flavor, lightly sweet but fairly dry. Nutty.  A bit astringent.  Medium-light bodied.

Dark red pour, little to no head. Aroma has hints of cherries and a bit of molasses. Flavor is straight forward, not syrupy sweet or too full of alcohol. Has accents of cherries and roasted nuts. Alcohol hiden extremely well. Mouthfeel could be a tad thicker. Pretty decent domestic bock.
Bottle. Malty nose. Tastes include vanilla, nuts, malt, chocolate, and bread. The mouthfeel is smooth. The finish is lingering and a little bitter. This is a nice chewy big beer. Excellent.

This beer struggles to make a head and gives up early leaving maybe a quater inch.  Nose of something sweet-like syurp  There is bitter chocolate and toffee, amazing, and then a linger of alcohol and vanilla (maybe?!?).  This beer gets more potent and hazelnuttish? as it ends. Very enjoyable, and I hope to acquire a full six pack one day.

Bottle. deep amber tinted brown with a thin flat tan head. nice sweet caramel toffee aroma. bitter roated chocolate flavor with a nice bittersweet finish. This could definitely keep me going in the winter.

Dark, chestnut body with a thick, light tan head.  Sweet, malty nose of caramel, nuts, chocolate, toasted whole grain bread and light hops.  The body is clean and full of flavor, though not entirely exquisite in the mouth.  The flavors are fairly reminiscent of the aroma--no real surprises or shifts in balance.  Mostly sweet and focused on the strong malt character.  Chocolate, caramel and nuts make the strongest impressions.  The hops have a nice balancing bitterness at the finish.  The end is not too long and has a warmth adequate for the winter.  Not all that amazing, but still a solid offering from New Glarus.

Bottle pours a deep reddish amber, fizzly off-white head, light carbonation, with spotty lacing. &nbsp Aroma was a pleasant maltiness with hints of caramel. &nbsp Nice flavor up front, a slightly chewy maltiness, a bit sweet, with some toffee/caramel mixed in. &nbsp Quick finish, and a little less than medium on the mouthfeel. &nbsp Overall not bad, but somewhat light. &nbsp Thanks goes out to CaptainCougar for the trade!

12 oz bottle:  clear burnt orange-brown.  Dense vanilla-tan froth.  Malt based aroma with spicy red grapes, grainy bread and hazelnuts.  Wonderful malt texture on the tongue.  Strong spicy pepper and dark, chewy fruits  plums & raisins most notably.  Quick finish that leaves a dry sticky filmpretty nice.

deep mahogony color with a quickly diminishing head with a good amount of carbonation.  smells of sweet malt and carmel...very good flavors of malt, carmel, toasted nuts, and hints of toffee, coffee, and chocolate.  excellent complex flavors with a nice smooth finish.

i had this up in madison last night. it was darn warm up there. it would make a nice winter warmer. it doesn't mesh with breadsticks too well, but anyway... a little coffee adds a bit of oomph-da. it's nice. smooth, sweet chocolate/toffee, with a little spice and coffee to provide a welcome pecularity.

Good stuff, once again, from New Glarus, who constantly delivers with quality product.  A lovely reddish brown in the glass, but oddly there's not head at all.  It looks rather Coke-like.  There's a light chocolate malt aroma, but the flavor explodes with toffee, caramel, chocolate, all lightly sweet and with a hint of bitterness.  The folks at Shiner Brewing need to try some REAL bock sometime, like this stuff.  The 7.3% abv is pretty well-hidden, as well.  I can scarcely taste it.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2004 Brilliant mahogany, quickly dissipating head.  Malty sweet aromas, very subtle spicy hops.  Gingerbread, toast, roasty coffee flavors.  Don't be so humble, Dan, call this a dopplebock.
GABF '03, light brown in color with a small white head.Aroma and flavors of malt,caramel and toffee.
Dark ruby brown color with a tan head.  Aroma had hints of caramel, toffee, and chocolate.  Flavor is subtle chocolate with a light coffee finish.
dark in colour thin quickly discipating head, malts in the nose somewhat watery. Same goes in the taste. Probably the best thing about this stuff is that it is very easily drinkable.
I'm not a big bock fan. But this one was smooth. Head vanished quickly but left a nice lacing.

Thanks wawood!  Medium to deep brown with reddish accents, OK head that died fast.  Nice aroma, somewhat sweet, notes of chocolate and dark fruit.  Flavor matched, more chocolate at first, becoming fruity and sweet as it warmed.  Bocks will never be my favorite, but this was a nice beer.

Uff-da indeed! This is a surprisingly good beer despite the unassuming label and name only the priveledged can understand. Malty rich, beautiful color, a very nice bock! Think I'll have another if it comes my way again. Recomended.

Poured nice and smooth with a nice ag sized head.  Color was a darker brown and when held up to a light you could see through it.  Taste was chocolaty and smooth.  I like and would recommend to anyone.

Finally the along awaited for Uff-da bock has finally come to my house.Thanks to Wawood.Medium brown color with a light reddish hue to it.The head was small and short lived but did leave a small swirl in the middle of the glass.Malty caramel aroma with a slight dried fruit presence.The flavoe was malty caramel and a bit thin bodied.There is a light chocolate tone to it but it doesn't get very pronounced and the coffee that they mention doesn't come on until the tail end and it's a bit weak but the hops do manage to make a nice mild appearance and i guess over all this is a pretty decent brew,very drinkable in volume.I think i could drink this brew everyday.Nicely done but needs just a slight tweek to make it better.

aroma is caramelly. slightly nutty, slightly earthen. Dark red/brown color. Medium sized light tan head. Medium carbo retention after pour, flavor slightly stronger than aroma (I dont have the best nose on earth), sweet burnt carmel flavor not overly strong - Nice finish - if I had to guess the ABV I would have been way off due to the smoothness, I would have guessed around 5 - at 7.2 its a job well done (as usual) by New Glarus

Rich, caramelly malt aroma with hints of chocolate. Deep red in color with an avg.-sized off-white head. Nice lace. I probably shouldn't be rating this beer after eating raw onions, but what can you do? Flavor matches the aroma. Rich, well-balanced brew. More on the malt side than hop side, but there is an alcoholic zing that keeps things interesting. Some faint hints of bourbon as it warms. This is a beer with complexity and worthy of my recommendation.

Bottle pours a deep garnet red with a small head that dissipates rapidly leaving no lace.  The aroma is malty almost resembling maple syrup with a hint of ripe banana.  The flavor is caramel and maple like.  The palate is ever so slightly rich and clean finishing.  Another fine one from New Glarus.

Another GABF sampled one ounce marathon. Tellin' ya it ain't always easy to get the best out of a good beer this way. The strain on my face must have been hilarious at times - trying to smell from this narrow vessel and filter out the noise and other distractions. A good beer, this I could tell. Good malts used. Fine aroma (from what I could tell, though some imagination was used). Gimme another. Maybe I'll even make my way to brewery to give 'em all another chance.
Deep red.  Bready nose, some toffee.  Lightly chocolate, very malty.  Lightly sweet and tart, finishes with a strong toffee character.  Nice palate, lightly creamy, quite nice.

Deep rich mahogany color with minimal head.  Sweet aroma of raisins.  Strong maple syrup flavor with dark chocolate and a bit of hazelnut coffee.  The sweetnes definitely pick up as the beer warms and masks some of the alcohol.  I feel flush

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2003 Bottled. Whew! This is the first big bock that was worthy of the name. There's a slightly hazy beer-bottle-brown body under a transient ochre head. Funny, I can't taste anything that says coffee, but instead a fruity alelike nose and tastes of raisins, rum and maple syrup. Also a warming alcohol presence and a slighty winey finish. Maybe the difference is that my bottle had been cellared a few years, but this tastes more like a microbrewed porter or a young barleywine. So try holding on to this for a while, and see if it doesn't do the same for you!

Great aroma, the coffee came out, predominantly.  Some carmel notes.  Good head.  On the palate, the coffee still predominated over any chocolate.  Fairly smooth, as far as alcohol was concerned.  Didn't feel to heavy, either.

This poured out wonderfully with a growing tall head of very tight frothyness of light tannish color sitting atop a glowing deep mahagony, rubyish copper highlighted gem of a bottom. Head did fade pretty fast though to a skim always present and a fairly thick ring. Smell is faint malts and light roastyness, no tang or sweetness to be found, will that carry over to the taste? Yep, kinda, its a whole lotta empty malts that renders some roastyness and seems to be quite solid and smooth but no other characteristics can be found. Hops are there in very small amount lending a bit of a grab with some roasted grains and thank goodness for that, other wise I might fall asleep drinkin this bock. Has no real finishing qualities either. Kinda bland and one dimensional. Feel is medium bodied smoothness with a small pickup near the middle. Its a decent drinkable tastin bock, a bit lack luster but do-able over many others of this style.
Sparkling brown, lasting beige head. Good malt nose. Full bodied malt profile with no noticeable alcohol. Rather bland

Light brown copper color with a soft white head and malty aroma.  Body is full, sweet, and smooth with some chocolate notes and a hint of coffee.  Finishes dry and sweet.  Good bock flavor and highly drinkable.
Little head retention.  Subtle malt aroma.  Roasted malt flavor throughout.  Finishes slightly dry to more you drink.  A good example of the style.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2004 vibrant amber body, big frothy head.  Spicy, woody, ripe fruits and alcohol as well as some spices.  Caramel and some chocolate notes.  Real creamyu.  Rich, full, sweet and deliscious.  Dry barley notes and ripe fruits plus some maple and toffee.

My goodness, thhis is like an Aass Bock clone.  Big bocky malty aroma, simple caramel flavor.  Sweet, but not overly so.  Remarkably clear, rust brown appearance.  Basic bockbier.  Major thanks to LiebeBier for toting this one back from Wisc.
(draft):  Clear dark copper with small beige head.  Medium sweet caramel aroma.  Taste is sweet, caramel.  Medium body, slightly syrupy.

A deliciously flavorful beer that passes the simple but decisive test: I would happily buy it again. Which, given that I live in Wisconsin where New Glarus is a local brand, is a more than likely possibility.
fruity/toffee sweet aroma, brown/red appearance, sweet, buttery, some spiciness, lots of maple, and some fruity notes mostly apples, Thanks Jean and Grumpy Ass
Draft - Light to medium brown beer with limited head.  Malty aroma.  This beer was great.  Slightly sweet malty flavor with nice hop quality and chocalte/toffee finish.

Dry finish, yet the flavor is a bit sweet due to all of the malts.  It is definetly not the most malty of bocks, but it is smooth and mild.  Easy to drink.  The alcohol is non-existent in the flavor and the aroma.  A gint of cloves and other spices.  Dark amber body, little head.

Well, this is a rather anticlimactic number 300 for me, but what the hell, I've been having a good beer night up until now.  Nice copper color, but zero head - bland aroma, slight cloves - flavor has a slight caramel touch with a tiny clove bitterness - I don't sense anything the commercial description suggests at all - if you want an accurate description of this beer, just think of it as everything the company's description is not.
A so-so bock. Watery and brown-sugar sweet. Great name, tired beer. No finish what so ever. Cheap as far as local beer goes.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing. Body is clear dark orange-brown. Aroma is moderately malty (nutty, toasted dark bread, caramel), lightly hoppy (herbs), with a note of brown sugar, hint of toffee. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Medium body, watery (almost syrupy) texture, lively carbonation. A bit too sugary/syrupy sweet (so contrary to the implication on the label, do NOT let it get too warm), but a pretty decent aroma. Hey, at least they're not dumping Cascades in here. Didn't notice any alcohol.

Really beautiful dark reddish, amber, copper color.  Very enjoyable nose with a slight candy sugar smell.  Caramel wheat, with a very slight taste of hops in the end.  Alcohol sweet on the breath.  Fizzy texture.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2003 This is a truly great beer from a truly great brewery.  This one had it all, a robust color, a deep flavor, very nice indeed it was. Truly is a big beer, I would love to try this stuff on the tap though.
A Beautiful deep red color and a rich malty aroma with hints of alcohol set up a rich, strongly cherry fruity malt flavour.  A great bock!
Nice big roasted malt nose on this brew. Nice creamy palate with a bitter roasted malt profile. A little sweetness finishes this one off just right. Thanks to maxpower for this fine brew.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2003 Rich caramel in color with a nice blondish head. Nice and smooth with a rich complexity hard to tease apart for me. I notice hints of the the 7.3 ABV.  Update: only slightly chilled - I thing this brew has a second to none palate.

This is one of the best domestic bocks that I have had.  Beautifully crafted dark auburn hues.  Little to no head.  The malt complexty overwhelms ... sweet, caramel, grainy, slight roastedness.  A wonderful brew and well worth a try.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2003 Brown color, thin white head,sweet and fruity aroma , very malty with a strange tasting sweetness, not bad for an American bock, not great for a bock either, I am aging a bottle for awhile to see if it gets better.
Metallic mokaccino foam atop hefty malt ruby...Smooth smoke perfume reveals old cherry ashes underneath...Honest bock which will not wake much up...
UPDATED: DEC 7, 2003 Had a sort of spicy, unpleasant taste.  I was disapointed, expecting something along the lines of Leinie's Bock.
Had a slightly off-putting color.  Overly swwet, medium body.  Ive had better, but hey, Ive also had worse.
Nice bock from the land of cheese. Good caramel, toffee flavors that i love in a bock. A bit thin in the body. A nice beer for fall afternoons watching football on the tube.
A big, malty bock that seems closer to a dopplebock. Roasted chocolate malt flavor that finishes with somewhat of a bite.

Liquid Lunch.  Malty aroma. Chestnut color with a light cream colored head.  Malt all over the place in the flavors.  Slightly burnt caramel, german chocolate, and dark malt. Nice to chew on a domestic bock with body.  Finishes slightly dry with a touch of graininess.
I thought it was very good.  almost as good as leinies big butt.

Standard bock appearance.  Weak aroma, lightly acidic and barley a hint of malt, for shame.  Not really much to note here, other than this is an average, rather boring, unoffensive beer.  It seems possible to me that this is quite variable from batch to batch, cos I remember this being better a few months ago when I first had it.

Interesting crimson color, with a thick, but quickly dissipated, orange head. Almost no aroma. Early taste is that of dark chocolate. Moves to more of a coffee flavor as it warms. Tasted nuts occasionally too. The alcohol became significantly more pronounced by the middle of the beer. The chocolate was back by the end, but the bite from the alcohol was still present. A decent sipping beer, but not something Ill drink regularly.

I have never given such disparate marks to aroma and flavor. A malt lovers dream in the nose, this became indistinct and muddied in the mouth. I maybe got a bit of chocolate, no coffeeishness, high alcohol. Chewy, which helped (this would have been really terrible with a super-thin body). Ive got to get a deeper bock understanding, I do believe.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Gorgeous crystal clear dark copper. Thin creamy white head. Very light carbonation. Little aroma, like spent grain and light sulfur. Initially rough with a hard water like harshness. Light cherry and burnt chocolate underbelly. Medium bodied. Light crispness. This is OK at times but has a very hard edge that irks me. Very little depth of malt flavor as well. Finishes nutty sweet and a little more hefty in alcohol, but this is merely eh.
This wonderfully rich and complex beer is worth several pilgrimages to New Glarus.
Red/brown in color.  Slight aroma.  Dry aftertaste, very light.  Slight alcohol notes, very smooth.  Sweet.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2016 I have not had many bocks in my day, but this is a pleasant suprise.  I like this beer-lots of carbonation, nice sweet nose, but the head was lacking.  Nice ruby red color.  New Glarus is one of the best micros in the midwest!!!
Wow! 14 years since my first rating of this.  Crazy!  Big caramel toasted malt toffee on the nose.  Flavors exhibit similar however has a bit of husky quality which I really like.  Great bock for sure!

Deep red in color; Head was gone in a flash; Nose was transperant. Dry right away. Wheres the malt? Very dissappointing. Maltiness begins to emerge at the 1/2 mark, but it is too little too late. A bit of sourness also reared its ugly head at the 2/3 mark. Thanks to TannerTavernBoy.

Not just a great name, but a fabulous flavor, probably my favorite 6-pack bottled beer.  
At half the price, Id take this any day over Celebrator, but I can see its a lighter bock beer, not so impressive in style, more common, however I prefer the taste, especially cold, the caramel, chocolate coffee undertones, just a great flavor, almost sexy.  Uff-da rules!
Very watered down for a Bock beer.  Not much flavor or aroma to speak of.
A great bock, dark in color but low in carbonation.  Tastes spicy with sweet, almost chocolaty undertones.
A great bock.  Slightly flat, not much head, but great spicy flavor. Malty, roasty, and smooth.  Light bitterness.
Just great stuff.  Rather spicy and vinous with heavy yet graceful malts.
A really nice American bock.  Sometimes I dont get a very nice head on my glass, but a nice malty treat.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2016 (October 2016): 12 ounce bottle from Badger Spirits in Beloit, WI, served a bit below cellar temp in a Hoegaarden mug.  Creamy light tan head topping a deep transulent caramel body dies at some speed leaving minimal lacing...lightly smoky, caramel-laden aroma, hints of figs or dates, faint herbal notes...sweet, bready caramel malts expectedly dominate the body, very light warming alcohol notes and a touch of pepperiness at the drier finish...body rather light for style but not watery; carbonation somewhat strong; something of a root beer character to the whole thing.  Still a pretty solid beer, but forgive my youthful exuberance 15 years ago - its hardly a masterpiece.  Rating is for this sampling.

(October 2001):  Spicy, strong nose on a beautiful ruby-red body; very assertive sweet, full-bodied bock flavor with a bit of caramel and holiday breads; end is a bit too hoppy, but this is still an almost-classic.  WISCONSIN BEERS RULE!  RERATING -- palate seems smoother, nose and flavor even stronger; yes, it seems more like a doppelbock; a great, great beer.  Original rating 4.4
Sweet caramel aroma. Taste brings out the distinct flavor of plums that continues through the finish.
Another GREAT Wisconsin Bock.

I go out of my way to get to Wisconsin
to get to this beer, and I live in east 
Tennessee!  This is a great low-carbonation
beer, best served around 40 degrees, when
the flavor really comes through.  Wonderful 
with dinner.
